LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The guide nodded gravely. “Yes, Sahib. The poor woman will be burned alive with her husband’s corpse. It is the custom of the land.”  

Sir Francis Cromarty clenched his fists in silent fury. Though he was a soldier accustomed to discipline and restraint, the barbarity of the ritual sickened him. He had heard of the practice of suttee—where widows were forced to immolate themselves upon their husbands’ funeral pyres—but witnessing it firsthand was another matter entirely. The procession moved slowly, the wails of the mourners mingling with the rhythmic beating of drums. The widow, draped in white, walked with a vacant stare, her fate sealed by tradition and superstition.  

Phileas Fogg, standing beside Sir Francis, observed the scene with his usual detachment. “A most disagreeable ceremony,” he remarked coolly.  

“Disagreeable?” Sir Francis exclaimed. “It is monstrous! The poor woman is being led to her death!”  

Fogg adjusted his cuffs. “Undoubtedly. But we are strangers in this country, and it is not our place to interfere with its customs.”  

Passepartout, who had been listening, could contain himself no longer. “But Monsieur, surely we cannot stand by and let this happen!”  

The guide, sensing their distress, leaned in. “The woman is not going willingly. She has been drugged with opium and hemp. Often, the relatives force them, fearing dishonor if they refuse.”  

Sir Francis turned to Fogg, his voice urgent. “Fogg, we must do something. There must be a way to save her.”  

Fogg considered for a moment, then glanced at his watch. “We have twelve hours before our train departs. Any delay would disrupt my schedule.”  

Passepartout groaned inwardly. Even in the face of such horror, his master’s obsession with punctuality remained unshaken.  

Suddenly, an idea struck the young Frenchman. “Monsieur Fogg, what if rescuing her does not delay us? What if we can save her and still make the train?”  

Fogg raised an eyebrow. “Explain.”  

Passepartout’s eyes gleamed with excitement. “The pyre is outside the village, near the jungle. If we act quickly, we could spirit her away before the flames are lit. The darkness and confusion would cover our escape.”  

Sir Francis nodded eagerly. “It could work. With a bit of luck, we might even convince the locals that the gods spared her.”  

Fogg exhaled slowly, then gave a curt nod. “Very well. But we must be precise. Any misstep, and we risk missing our connection to Calcutta.”  

Under the cover of night, the three men, along with the guide, crept toward the funeral site. The mourners, intoxicated by ritual and narcotics, paid little attention as Passepartout and Sir Francis stealthily approached the drugged widow. With swift efficiency, they lifted her from the pyre just as the flames began to rise.  

A cry went up from the crowd, but in the chaos, the rescuers slipped into the jungle, carrying the unconscious woman to safety. By the time the villagers realized what had happened, the train was already pulling away from the station, the widow safely hidden aboard.  

As the engine chugged into the night, Sir Francis sighed in relief. “You have done a noble thing today, Fogg.”  

Fogg merely checked his watch. “We have saved forty-seven minutes. That is efficiency.”  

Passepartout grinned. Somewhere beneath that cold exterior, he was certain, beat the heart of a hero.

events.title: Fogg Proposes a Rescue Mission
detailed_summary: The guide brings Kiouni out from hiding and mounts him.
As the guide prepares to signal the elephant forward, Mr. Fogg stops him.

Sir Francis expresses surprise at the suggestion.

events.text_segment:
The guide now led the elephant out of the thicket, and leaped upon his neck. Just at the moment that he was about to urge Kiouni forward with a peculiar whistle, Mr. Fogg stopped him, and, turning to Sir Francis Cromarty, said, “Suppose we save this woman.”
“Save the woman, Mr. Fogg!”
“I have yet twelve hours to spare; I can devote them to that.”
“Why, you are a man of heart!”
“Sometimes,” replied Phileas Fogg, quietly; “when I have the time.”

The guide concurs and provides details about the victim, Aouda: a beautiful, wealthy Parsee merchant's daughter with an English education, appearing European in manner. Orphaned, she was unwillingly married to an old rajah, escaped, was recaptured, and condemned to death by relatives interested in her demise.
Aouda's story solidifies the group's determination to proceed with their rescue plan.
They decide the guide will navigate the elephant toward the pagoda of Pillaji.
They arrive near the pagoda and halt in a concealed copse, close enough to hear the cries from the ceremony site.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They halted, half an hour afterwards, in a copse, some five hundred feet from the pagoda, where they were well concealed; but they could hear the groans and cries of the fakirs distinctly.

events.text_segment:
The project was a bold one, full of difficulty, perhaps impracticable. Mr. Fogg was going to risk life, or at least liberty, and therefore the success of his tour. But he did not hesitate, and he found in Sir Francis Cromarty an enthusiastic ally.
As for Passepartout, he was ready for anything that might be proposed. His master’s idea charmed him; he perceived a heart, a soul, under that icy exterior. He began to love Phileas Fogg.
There remained the guide: what course would he adopt? Would he not take part with the Indians? In default of his assistance, it was necessary to be assured of his neutrality.
Sir Francis frankly put the question to him.
“Officers,” replied the guide, “I am a Parsee, and this woman is a Parsee. Command me as you will.”
“Excellent!” said Mr. Fogg.
“However,” resumed the guide, “it is certain, not only that we shall risk our lives, but horrible tortures, if we are taken.”
“That is foreseen,” replied Mr. Fogg. “I think we must wait till night before acting.”
“I think so,” said the guide.
The worthy Indian then gave some account of the victim, who, he said, was a celebrated beauty of the Parsee race, and the daughter of a wealthy Bombay merchant. She had received a thoroughly English education in that city, and, from her manners and intelligence, would be thought an European. Her name was Aouda. Left an orphan, she was married against her will to the old rajah of Bundelcund; and, knowing the fate that awaited her, she escaped, was retaken, and devoted by the rajah’s relatives, who had an interest in her death, to the sacrifice from which it seemed she could not escape.
The Parsee’s narrative only confirmed Mr. Fogg and his companions in their generous design. It was decided that the guide should direct the elephant towards the pagoda of Pillaji, which he accordingly approached as quickly as possible. They halted, half an hour afterwards, in a copse, some five hundred feet from the pagoda, where they were well concealed; but they could hear the groans and cries of the fakirs distinctly.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The project was a bold one, full of difficulty, perhaps impracticable. Yet Phileas Fogg, with his characteristic calm and precision, had calculated every detail. To circumnavigate the globe in eighty days—a feat never before attempted—required not only unwavering determination but also an unshakable faith in the precision of modern travel. Railways, steamships, and even the occasional elephant or sledge would serve as his conveyances, each timed to the minute.  

The skeptics scoffed, the doubters wagered against him, and even his loyal servant, Passepartout, harbored private misgivings. But Fogg, ever the man of science and routine, saw no room for failure. The world, in his estimation, was a machine governed by immutable laws, and he intended to prove that even its vastness could be mastered by human will and punctuality.  

Yet the journey was fraught with unforeseen perils. Storms delayed ships, bandits threatened trains, and bureaucratic red tape entangled progress. At every turn, fate seemed to conspire against him, testing not only his schedule but his very resolve. And then there was Detective Fix, dogging his steps, convinced that Fogg was a fugitive from justice—a complication that threatened to derail everything.  

Through it all, Fogg remained imperturbable. Whether rescuing a damsel in distress in India or racing across the American plains, his composure never wavered. Time, that relentless adversary, ticked away, and as the days dwindled, so too did the margin for error.  

And yet, when all seemed lost—when he arrived in London a full day behind schedule—Fogg discovered a miscalculation. By crossing the International Date Line, he had gained a day. With minutes to spare, he strode into the Reform Club, victorious. The impossible had been achieved.  

In the end, the journey was more than a wager—it was a testament to human ingenuity, perseverance, and the unyielding belief that even the greatest challenges could be conquered with resolve. And for Phileas Fogg, the man who had defied time itself, the world would never seem quite so large again.

events.title: Pagoda Reconnaissance and Initial Assessment
detailed_summary: The group deliberates on the best method to reach Aouda inside the pagoda.
The guide, knowledgeable about the pagoda, confirms Aouda's confinement within.
Two potential strategies are considered: entering through a door while the Indians are incapacitated by drugs, or creating an opening in the walls.
They determine the final approach must be decided on-site but agree the abduction must occur that night, before the dawn sacrifice makes rescue impossible.
Around six o'clock, as night descends, they proceed with a reconnaissance mission.
The fakirs' chanting subsides as the Indians begin using opium and hemp, offering a potential window for infiltration.
Guided by the Parsee, they stealthily advance through the woods.
They reach a small stream, observing by torchlight the funeral pyre prepared with the rajah's body, awaiting Aouda.
The pagoda structure is visible nearby through the darkening trees.
The guide urges them forward, moving with increased caution through the undergrowth.
They arrive at the edge of a torchlit clearing where numerous Indians lie motionless in a drunken stupor.
The pagoda is clearly visible, but armed guards are actively patrolling the entrances, disappointing the guide.
Concluding that forcing entry through the guarded doors is infeasible, the guide leads the party back.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They then discussed the means of getting at the victim.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty also saw that nothing could be attempted in that direction.

events.text_segment:
They then discussed the means of getting at the victim. The guide was familiar with the pagoda of Pillaji, in which, as he declared, the young woman was imprisoned. Could they enter any of its doors while the whole party of Indians was plunged in a drunken sleep, or was it safer to attempt to make a hole in the walls? This could only be determined at the moment and the place themselves; but it was certain that the abduction must be made that night, and not when, at break of day, the victim was led to her funeral pyre. Then no human intervention could save her.
As soon as night fell, about six o’clock, they decided to make a reconnaissance around the pagoda. The cries of the fakirs were just ceasing; the Indians were in the act of plunging themselves into the drunkenness caused by liquid opium mingled with hemp, and it might be possible to slip between them to the temple itself.
The Parsee, leading the others, noiselessly crept through the wood, and in ten minutes they found themselves on the banks of a small stream, whence, by the light of the rosin torches, they perceived a pyre of wood, on the top of which lay the embalmed body of the rajah, which was to be burned with his wife. The pagoda, whose minarets loomed above the trees in the deepening dusk, stood a hundred steps away.
“Come!” whispered the guide.
He slipped more cautiously than ever through the brush, followed by his companions; the silence around was only broken by the low murmuring of the wind among the branches.
Soon the Parsee stopped on the borders of the glade, which was lit up by the torches. The ground was covered by groups of the Indians, motionless in their drunken sleep; it seemed a battlefield strewn with the dead. Men, women, and children lay together.
In the background, among the trees, the pagoda of Pillaji loomed distinctly. Much to the guide’s disappointment, the guards of the rajah, lighted by torches, were watching at the doors and marching to and fro with naked sabres; probably the priests, too, were watching within.
The Parsee, now convinced that it was impossible to force an entrance to the temple, advanced no farther, but led his companions back again. Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty also saw that nothing could be attempted in that direction.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
They then discussed the means of getting at the victim. Fix, the cunning detective, had been trailing Phileas Fogg since London, convinced that he was the notorious bank robber who had stolen £55,000 from the Bank of England. Now, in the bustling streets of Hong Kong, Fix saw his chance to finally arrest Fogg—but he needed a warrant, and time was running out.  

Passepartout, Fogg’s loyal servant, had unwittingly helped Fix by revealing their travel plans. However, Fix knew that if Fogg left Hong Kong before the warrant arrived, his pursuit would become infinitely more difficult. The detective paced the docks, his mind racing. He needed a way to delay Fogg’s departure—or, better yet, to separate him from his servant, who might unknowingly provide more information.  

Meanwhile, Fogg remained blissfully unaware of the danger closing in around him. His sole focus was on catching the next steamer to Yokohama, as every minute counted in his race against time. He had already sacrificed much to stay on schedule, and he would not let anything—or anyone—stand in his way.  

Fix considered his options. He could try to bribe the steamer’s crew to delay departure, but that was risky. Alternatively, he could involve the local authorities, but without the warrant, they might not cooperate. His best chance, he decided, was to isolate Passepartout and manipulate him into revealing something incriminating—or, at the very least, keep him occupied long enough to miss the ship.  

As the hours ticked by, Fix put his plan into action. He approached Passepartout under the guise of a fellow traveler, offering to show him the sights of Hong Kong. The trusting Frenchman, eager for adventure, agreed. Little did he know that every minute spent away from Fogg brought his master closer to disaster.  

By the time Passepartout realized the deception, it was nearly too late. The steamer was preparing to depart, and Fogg was already aboard—unaware that his loyal servant had been left behind. Fix, triumphant, watched as the ship pulled away from the dock. His trap had worked. Now, all he needed was for the warrant to arrive before Fogg reached his next destination.  

But the game was far from over. Passepartout, furious at the betrayal, swore to reunite with his master—no matter the cost. And Fogg, ever the unshakable gentleman, would soon find himself facing an even greater challenge than the ticking clock: the relentless pursuit of justice—or injustice—in the form of Detective Fix.

events.title: Thwarted Attempt to Breach the Pagoda Wall
detailed_summary: The group halts and discusses their options in hushed tones.
Sir Francis notes it is only eight o'clock and speculates the guards might eventually fall asleep.
The guide concedes it's a possibility.
They find cover at the base of a tree and settle in to wait.
Time drags on; the guide periodically ventures out to check the guards' status.
The guards remain alert under the torchlight, and a faint light is visible from within the pagoda.
By midnight, hope diminishes as the guards show no signs of sleeping, making the wall-breaching plan necessary.
A remaining uncertainty is whether priests are guarding Aouda inside as vigilantly as the soldiers outside.
Following a final consultation, the guide signals readiness for the attempt.
They navigate a circuitous route to approach the pagoda from the rear.
They reach the back walls around half-past twelve, encountering no one; this area lacks guards, windows, or doors.
The darkness of the waning, cloud-covered moon and dense trees aids their concealment.
Acknowledging the need to create an opening, they rely on their pocket-knives.
The temple's brick and wood construction seems amenable to their tools.
The guide and Passepartout begin quietly working to remove bricks, aiming for a two-foot wide aperture.
Their progress is suddenly interrupted by a cry from inside, quickly answered by cries from outside.
Fearing detection and an alarm, they prudently withdraw into the woods, led by Fogg and Sir Francis.
They wait, prepared to resume, but guards unexpectedly appear and take positions at the rear of the temple, blocking their planned entry point.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They stopped, and engaged in a whispered colloquy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It would be difficult to describe the disappointment of the party, thus interrupted in their work.

events.text_segment:
They stopped, and engaged in a whispered colloquy.
“It is only eight now,” said the brigadier, “and these guards may also go to sleep.”
“It is not impossible,” returned the Parsee.
They lay down at the foot of a tree, and waited.
The time seemed long; the guide ever and anon left them to take an observation on the edge of the wood, but the guards watched steadily by the glare of the torches, and a dim light crept through the windows of the pagoda.
They waited till midnight; but no change took place among the guards, and it became apparent that their yielding to sleep could not be counted on. The other plan must be carried out; an opening in the walls of the pagoda must be made. It remained to ascertain whether the priests were watching by the side of their victim as assiduously as were the soldiers at the door.
After a last consultation, the guide announced that he was ready for the attempt, and advanced, followed by the others. They took a roundabout way, so as to get at the pagoda on the rear. They reached the walls about half-past twelve, without having met anyone; here there was no guard, nor were there either windows or doors.
The night was dark. The moon, on the wane, scarcely left the horizon, and was covered with heavy clouds; the height of the trees deepened the darkness.
It was not enough to reach the walls; an opening in them must be accomplished, and to attain this purpose the party only had their pocket-knives. Happily the temple walls were built of brick and wood, which could be penetrated with little difficulty; after one brick had been taken out, the rest would yield easily.
They set noiselessly to work, and the Parsee on one side and Passepartout on the other began to loosen the bricks so as to make an aperture two feet wide. They were getting on rapidly, when suddenly a cry was heard in the interior of the temple, followed almost instantly by other cries replying from the outside. Passepartout and the guide stopped. Had they been heard? Was the alarm being given? Common prudence urged them to retire, and they did so, followed by Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis. They again hid themselves in the wood, and waited till the disturbance, whatever it might be, ceased, holding themselves ready to resume their attempt without delay. But, awkwardly enough, the guards now appeared at the rear of the temple, and there installed themselves, in readiness to prevent a surprise.
It would be difficult to describe the disappointment of the party, thus interrupted in their work.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  

They stopped, and engaged in a whispered colloquy.  

"It is only eight now," said the brigadier; "and these guards may also go to sleep."  

"It is not impossible," returned the guide.  

They stretched themselves at the foot of a tree, and waited.  

The time seemed long; the guide alone ventured out from time to time to observe the position of the sentinels. The latter still watched by the light of their torches, and a dim light shone through the windows of the pagoda.  

They waited till midnight; but no change took place among the guards, and it became apparent that their yielding to sleep could not be counted on. Another plan must be tried. After a brief consultation, the guide announced that he was ready to set out again, followed by the others. They took a roundabout way, so as to get at the pagoda on the rear.  

About half-past twelve they reached the foot of the walls, without having met any one. No watch was kept on this side, but there were neither windows nor doors.  

The night was dark. The moon, on the wane, scarcely left the horizon, and was covered with heavy clouds; the height of the trees deepened the darkness.  

It was not enough to reach the walls; an opening in them must be accomplished, and for this purpose the party had only their pocket-knives. Happily, the temple walls were of brick and wood, which could be penetrated with little difficulty. Once a brick was removed, it would be easy to pull out enough to make an aperture two feet wide.  

They set noiselessly to work, and the Parsee on one side and Passepartout on the other began to loosen the bricks so as to make an opening. They were getting on rapidly, when suddenly a cry was heard in the interior of the temple, followed almost instantly by other cries replying from the outside.  

Passepartout and the guide stopped. Had they been heard? Was the alarm being given? Common prudence urged them to retire, and they did so, followed by Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis. They again hid themselves in the wood, and waited till the disturbance, whatever it might be, should cease, holding themselves ready to resume their attempt without delay. But, awkwardly enough, the guards now appeared at the rear of the temple, and there installed themselves, in readiness to prevent a surprise.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
They stopped, and engaged in a whispered colloquy. The night was thick with tension, the air heavy with the scent of damp earth and distant smoke. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, stood with his hands clasped behind his back, his sharp eyes scanning the darkened path ahead. Passepartout, ever the loyal servant, shifted nervously from foot to foot, his usual cheerfulness subdued by the gravity of their situation.  

“We must proceed with caution,” Fogg murmured, his voice barely audible above the rustling leaves. “The slightest misstep could cost us dearly.”  

Passepartout nodded, though his brow furrowed with concern. “But sir, if we delay any longer, we risk missing the next train—and with it, our chance to stay on schedule.”  

Fogg’s lips tightened imperceptibly. Time, that relentless adversary, was indeed their greatest foe. Every second counted in their audacious wager to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. Yet recklessness could prove just as fatal as hesitation.  

A distant sound—a twig snapping underfoot—sent a jolt through Passepartout. “Did you hear that?” he whispered, his hand instinctively reaching for the small knife he carried.  

Fogg’s gaze remained steady. “Perhaps an animal. Or perhaps not.” He motioned for silence, his ears straining for further clues. The stillness of the night seemed to press in around them, amplifying every whisper of wind, every creak of the trees.  

Then, like a specter emerging from the shadows, a figure materialized before them—a tall, cloaked stranger whose face was obscured by the brim of a wide hat. Passepartout’s breath hitched, but Fogg, ever unflappable, merely inclined his head.  

“You travel late, gentlemen,” the stranger observed, his voice smooth yet edged with something unreadable.  

“Necessity knows no hour,” Fogg replied coolly. “And you?”  

The stranger chuckled, a sound that sent an inexplicable chill down Passepartout’s spine. “Let us say I have a vested interest in your journey.”  

Before either could react, the stranger stepped closer, the moonlight glinting off something metallic in his hand. Passepartout’s heart raced, but Fogg’s demeanor never wavered.  

“If it is money you seek,” Fogg said evenly, “you will find our purses light. But if it is trouble you offer, you will find it in abundance.”  

The stranger paused, as if weighing the words. Then, with a sudden, mocking bow, he stepped back into the shadows. “Until we meet again, Mr. Fogg.”  

And just like that, he was gone, leaving behind only the echo of his words and the lingering sense of unease.  

Passepartout exhaled sharply. “What in blazes was that about?”  

Fogg adjusted his cuffs, his expression inscrutable. “A reminder, Passepartout, that our journey is fraught with more than just the challenges of time and distance. Come—we have a train to catch.”  

And with that, they pressed onward, the night swallowing their figures as the clock continued its inexorable countdown.

events.title: Rescue Appears Lost; Fogg Remains Hopeful
detailed_summary: The group is deeply dismayed, as reaching Aouda now seems impossible.
Sir Francis clenches his fists in frustration, Passepartout is extremely agitated, and the guide gnashes his teeth in anger.
Phileas Fogg remains outwardly calm and unemotional.
Sir Francis whispers that they have no option but to depart.
The guide concurs with this assessment of hopelessness.
Fogg firmly tells them to wait, reminding them he has until the next morning to reach Allahabad.
Sir Francis questions Fogg's hope, pointing out that dawn is approaching.
Fogg enigmatically suggests that the lost chance might reappear at the very last moment.
Sir Francis studies Fogg, trying to understand his cool demeanor and plan – perhaps a reckless attempt to snatch Aouda during the sacrifice itself.
Though considering Fogg's potential plan foolhardy, Sir Francis agrees to stay until the end.
The guide leads them to a position at the rear of the glade to watch the sleeping assembly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The guide led them to the rear of the glade, where they were able to observe the sleeping groups.

events.text_segment:
They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her? Sir Francis shook his fists, Passepartout was beside himself, and the guide gnashed his teeth with rage. The tranquil Fogg waited, without betraying any emotion.
“We have nothing to do but to go away,” whispered Sir Francis.
“Nothing but to go away,” echoed the guide.
“Stop,” said Fogg. “I am only due at Allahabad tomorrow before noon.”
“But what can you hope to do?” asked Sir Francis. “In a few hours it will be daylight, and—”
“The chance which now seems lost may present itself at the last moment.”
Sir Francis would have liked to read Phileas Fogg’s eyes. What was this cool Englishman thinking of? Was he planning to make a rush for the young woman at the very moment of the sacrifice, and boldly snatch her from her executioners?
This would be utter folly, and it was hard to admit that Fogg was such a fool. Sir Francis consented, however, to remain to the end of this terrible drama. The guide led them to the rear of the glade, where they were able to observe the sleeping groups.

They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her? Sir Francis clenched his hands, Passepartout was beside himself, and the guide gnashed his teeth with rage. The tranquil Fogg waited, without betraying any emotion.  

“We have nothing to do but to go away,” whispered Sir Francis.  

“Nothing but to go away,” echoed the guide.  

“Stop,” said Fogg. “I am only due at Allahabad tomorrow before noon.”  

“But what can you hope to do?” asked Sir Francis. “In a few hours it will be daylight, and—”  

“The chance which now seems lost may present itself at the last moment.”  

Sir Francis would have liked to read Phileas Fogg’s eyes. What was this cool Englishman thinking of? Was he planning to make a rush for the young woman at the very moment of the sacrifice, and boldly snatch her from her executioners?  

This would be utter folly, and it was hard to admit that Fogg was such a fool. Sir Francis consented, however, to remain to the end of this terrible drama. The guide led them to the rear of the glade, where they were able to observe the sleeping groups.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile Passepartout, who had perched himself on the lower branches of a tree, was resolving an idea which had at first struck him like a flash, and which was now firmly lodged in his brain.
He had commenced by saying to himself, “What folly!” and then he repeated, “Why not, after all? It’s a chance,—perhaps the only one; and with such sots!” Thinking thus, he slipped, with the suppleness of a serpent, to the lowest branches, the ends of which bent almost to the ground.
The hours passed, and the lighter shades now announced the approach of day, though it was not yet light. This was the moment. The slumbering multitude became animated, the tambourines sounded, songs and cries arose; the hour of the sacrifice had come. The doors of the pagoda swung open, and a bright light escaped from its interior, in the midst of which Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis espied the victim. She seemed, having shaken off the stupor of intoxication, to be striving to escape from her executioner. Sir Francis’s heart throbbed; and, convulsively seizing Mr. Fogg’s hand, found in it an open knife. Just at this moment the crowd began to move. The young woman had again fallen into a stupor caused by the fumes of hemp, and passed among the fakirs, who escorted her with their wild, religious cries.
Phileas Fogg and his companions, mingling in the rear ranks of the crowd, followed; and in two minutes they reached the banks of the stream, and stopped fifty paces from the pyre, upon which still lay the rajah’s corpse.

He had been turning the matter over ever since their arrival in India, and the sight of the sacred procession had only sharpened his thoughts.  

*If only we could use this to our advantage,* he mused, watching the distant flicker of torches as the priests continued their chants. The plan was daring—perhaps even reckless—but time was slipping away, and Mr. Fogg’s wager depended on swift action.  

Passepartout’s fingers drummed against the bark as he weighed the risks. The British authorities would certainly disapprove, and the consequences could be severe. Yet, if successful, it might shave precious hours off their journey. His loyalty to Fogg outweighed his caution, and with a determined nod, he slid down from the tree.  

He would need to act quickly and quietly. The cover of night would help, but timing was everything. Taking a deep breath, he crept toward the edge of the grove, his mind set on the boldest scheme he had ever conceived—one that might either save their voyage or doom it entirely.

The terrified fakirs, soldiers, and priests remain prostrate, not daring to look at the apparent supernatural event.
The spectral figure carries the lifeless Aouda with surprising ease.

The figure walks towards Fogg and Sir Francis and abruptly instructs them, "Let us be off!"

events.text_segment:
In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body. Then a torch was brought, and the wood, heavily soaked with oil, instantly took fire.
At this moment Sir Francis and the guide seized Phileas Fogg, who, in an instant of mad generosity, was about to rush upon the pyre. But he had quickly pushed them aside, when the whole scene suddenly changed. A cry of terror arose. The whole multitude prostrated themselves, terror-stricken, on the ground.
The old rajah was not dead, then, since he rose of a sudden, like a spectre, took up his wife in his arms, and descended from the pyre in the midst of the clouds of smoke, which only heightened his ghostly appearance.
Fakirs and soldiers and priests, seized with instant terror, lay there, with their faces on the ground, not daring to lift their eyes and behold such a prodigy.
The inanimate victim was borne along by the vigorous arms which supported her, and which she did not seem in the least to burden. Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis stood erect, the Parsee bowed his head, and Passepartout was, no doubt, scarcely less stupefied.
The resuscitated rajah approached Sir Francis and Mr. Fogg, and, in an abrupt tone, said, “Let us be off!”
It was Passepartout himself, who had slipped upon the pyre in the midst of the smoke and, profiting by the still overhanging darkness, had delivered the young woman from death! It was Passepartout who, playing his part with a happy audacity, had passed through the crowd amid the general terror.

The flickering torchlight cast eerie shadows across the scene, revealing the tragic aftermath of the ritual sacrifice. Her long dark hair was disheveled, and her rich garments, once vibrant, were now stained with dust and sorrow.  

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, knelt beside her, his usual stoic demeanor softened by a rare flicker of concern. He pressed two fingers to her wrist, checking for a pulse, while Passepartout hovered anxiously nearby. "She lives," Fogg announced quietly, his voice steady despite the grim surroundings.

The poor girl had narrowly escaped a gruesome fate, and the sight of her fallen husband—his lifeless eyes staring blankly at the sky—only deepened the horror of the moment.  

With swift efficiency, Fogg and Passepartout lifted Aouda and carried her away from the funeral pyre, their footsteps echoing in the silent night. The rescue had been daring, but the journey ahead was uncertain. Would she awaken? And if she did, what then? For now, the priority was safety—and time, as always, was of the essence.

Sir Francis pressed the worthy fellow’s hand, and his master said, “Well done!” which, from him, was high commendation; to which Passepartout replied that all the credit of the affair belonged to Mr. Fogg. As for him, he had only been struck with a “queer” idea; and he laughed to think that for a few moments he, Passepartout, the ex-gymnast, ex-sergeant fireman, had been the spouse of a charming woman, a venerable, embalmed rajah! events.title: Journey Continuation and Concerns for Aouda
detailed_summary: Guided skillfully by the Parsee, the elephant travels swiftly through the dark forest and across a plain.
They halt after about an hour's travel past the pagoda.
Aouda remains deeply unconscious; the guide administers brandy and water without effect.
Sir Francis, recognizing the symptoms of hemp intoxication, reassures the others about her current state.
However, he expresses grave concern for Aouda's future safety if she stays in India.
He warns Fogg that fanatics would find her anywhere in the country, even under English police protection.
Sir Francis concludes that leaving India permanently is her only path to safety.
Phileas Fogg states he will consider the situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

events.text_segment:
The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain. They made a halt at seven o’clock, the young woman being still in a state of complete prostration. The guide made her drink a little brandy and water, but the drowsiness which stupefied her could not yet be shaken off. Sir Francis, who was familiar with the effects of the intoxication produced by the fumes of hemp, reassured his companions on her account. But he was more disturbed at the prospect of her future fate. He told Phileas Fogg that, should Aouda remain in India, she would inevitably fall again into the hands of her executioners. These fanatics were scattered throughout the county, and would, despite the English police, recover their victim at Madras, Bombay, or Calcutta. She would only be safe by quitting India for ever.
Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

events.title: Arrival at Allahabad and Passepartout's Shopping Errand
detailed_summary: The group reaches the Allahabad railway station around ten o'clock.
The railway line continues from here, promising arrival in Calcutta within 24 hours.
This timing allows Fogg to catch the planned steamer to Hong Kong.
Aouda is settled in a waiting room.
Fogg tasks Passepartout with buying necessary clothing and toiletries for Aouda, giving him unlimited funds.
Passepartout ventures into Allahabad, noting its significance as the 'City of God' at the confluence of the Ganges and Jumna rivers.
He observes the city's landmarks, including its fort-turned-prison, and finds its commerce disappointing compared to London.
He eventually locates an elderly Jewish merchant selling second-hand goods.
Passepartout purchases a Scottish dress, a large mantle, and an otter-skin pelisse for seventy-five pounds.
He returns to the station, pleased with his purchases.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then returned triumphantly to the station.

events.text_segment:
The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Phileas Fogg would thus be able to arrive in time to take the steamer which left Calcutta the next day, October 25th, at noon, for Hong Kong.
The young woman was placed in one of the waiting-rooms of the station, whilst Passepartout was charged with purchasing for her various articles of toilet, a dress, shawl, and some furs; for which his master gave him unlimited credit. Passepartout started off forthwith, and found himself in the streets of Allahabad, that is, the City of God, one of the most venerated in India, being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers, Ganges and Jumna, the waters of which attract pilgrims from every part of the peninsula. The Ganges, according to the legends of the Ramayana, rises in heaven, whence, owing to Brahma’s agency, it descends to the earth.
Passepartout made it a point, as he made his purchases, to take a good look at the city. It was formerly defended by a noble fort, which has since become a state prison; its commerce has dwindled away, and Passepartout in vain looked about him for such a bazaar as he used to frequent in Regent Street. At last he came upon an elderly, crusty Jew, who sold second-hand articles, and from whom he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff, a large mantle, and a fine otter-skin pelisse, for which he did not hesitate to pay seventy-five pounds. He then returned triumphantly to the station.

According to the legends of the Ramayana, Allahabad stands on the site of the ancient city of Prayag, which, like Rome, was built on seven hills. Passepartout, while he made his purchases, took a hasty survey of the city, formerly defended by a noble fort, now converted into a prison. Its commerce has dwindled away, and Passepartout sought in vain for such a bazaar as he had delighted in at Regent Street. At last he found, in the house of a stubborn old Jew, the articles he required—a dress of Scotch stuff, a large mantle, and a fine otter-skin pelisse, for which he paid seventy-five pounds. Then, quite proud of his achievement, he returned to the station.  

---

Phileas Fogg would thus be able to arrive in time to take the steamer which left Calcutta the next day, October 25th, at noon, for Hong Kong.

The blended streams unite their waters in a broad river, on whose banks are ghats crowded with bathers. The streets of the city were alive with people—priests, soldiers, fakirs, merchants, and laborers. But he soon found that the commerce of the city was not on a par with its religious importance, and that the bazaars would have answered his wants no better than Regent Street.  

At last he came upon a crusty Jew, who sold second-hand articles, and from whom he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff, a large mantle, and a fine otter-skin pelisse, for which he did not hesitate to pay seventy-five pounds. Then, quite triumphant, he returned to the station.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, consulted his pocket watch and noted the time with satisfaction. The delay caused by the unfinished tracks had been overcome, and their journey was back on schedule.  

Passepartout, still recovering from the excitement of their elephant ride across the Indian countryside, stretched his legs on the platform. He marveled at the bustling station, where merchants hawked their wares and passengers hurried to board the waiting trains. The scent of spices and coal smoke filled the air, a vivid reminder of their exotic surroundings.  

Sir Francis Cromarty, who had accompanied them thus far, bid them farewell. "You are in good hands now," he assured Fogg. "The railway will take you straight to Calcutta without further hindrance." Fogg thanked him with his usual brevity, and the colonel departed for his military duties.  

As the train whistled and began its steady chug forward, Passepartout gazed out the window, watching the landscape blur into a tapestry of green fields and distant villages. He wondered what new adventures awaited them in Calcutta—and whether Detective Fix, who had been lurking suspiciously at the station, would cause further trouble.  

Fogg, meanwhile, remained absorbed in his calculations. Every minute counted, and he was determined not to lose his wager. The race against time continued.

events.title: Aouda's Recovery, Description, and Fogg's Generosity
detailed_summary: Aouda begins to recover from the effects of the drugs administered by the priests.
Her consciousness returns, and her eyes regain their gentle expression.
The narrative includes a poetic description of an Indian queen's beauty, implying Aouda possesses similar charms in a European sense.
She is noted to be a charming woman who speaks English purely, confirming the guide's assessment of her upbringing.
As the train prepares to depart, Fogg pays the guide the exact sum agreed upon.
Passepartout is surprised, feeling Fogg owes the guide more for his devotion and the risks taken.
He reflects on the danger the guide would face if caught by the Indians.
The question of what to do with the expensive elephant, Kiouni, arises.
Fogg resolves this by offering the elephant to the Parsee guide as a gift, acknowledging his devotion beyond the paid service.
The guide is overjoyed, recognizing the gift's immense value.
Passepartout applauds the gesture and bids farewell to Kiouni with sugar lumps.
The elephant affectionately lifts Passepartout with its trunk before gently setting him down.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

events.text_segment:
The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
When the poet-king, Ucaf Uddaul, celebrates the charms of the queen of Ahmehnagara, he speaks thus:
“Her shining tresses, divided in two parts, encircle the harmonious contour of her white and delicate cheeks, brilliant in their glow and freshness. Her ebony brows have the form and charm of the bow of Kama, the god of love, and beneath her long silken lashes the purest reflections and a celestial light swim, as in the sacred lakes of Himalaya, in the black pupils of her great clear eyes. Her teeth, fine, equal, and white, glitter between her smiling lips like dewdrops in a passion-flower’s half-enveloped breast. Her delicately formed ears, her vermilion hands, her little feet, curved and tender as the lotus-bud, glitter with the brilliancy of the loveliest pearls of Ceylon, the most dazzling diamonds of Golconda. Her narrow and supple waist, which a hand may clasp around, sets forth the outline of her rounded figure and the beauty of her bosom, where youth in its flower displays the wealth of its treasures; and beneath the silken folds of her tunic she seems to have been modelled in pure silver by the godlike hand of Vicvarcarma, the immortal sculptor.”
It is enough to say, without applying this poetical rhapsody to Aouda, that she was a charming woman, in all the European acceptation of the phrase. She spoke English with great purity, and the guide had not exaggerated in saying that the young Parsee had been transformed by her bringing up.
The train was about to start from Allahabad, and Mr. Fogg proceeded to pay the guide the price agreed upon for his service, and not a farthing more; which astonished Passepartout, who remembered all that his master owed to the guide’s devotion. He had, indeed, risked his life in the adventure at Pillaji, and, if he should be caught afterwards by the Indians, he would with difficulty escape their vengeance. Kiouni, also, must be disposed of. What should be done with the elephant, which had been so dearly purchased? Phileas Fogg had already determined this question.
“Parsee,” said he to the guide, “you have been serviceable and devoted. I have paid for your service, but not for your devotion. Would you like to have this elephant? He is yours.”
The guide’s eyes glistened.
“Your honour is giving me a fortune!” cried he.
“Take him, guide,” returned Mr. Fogg, “and I shall still be your debtor.”
“Good!” exclaimed Passepartout. “Take him, friend. Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast.” And, going up to the elephant, he gave him several lumps of sugar, saying, “Here, Kiouni, here, here.”
The elephant grunted out his satisfaction, and, clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk, lifted him as high as his head. Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

```text
"The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression. She was, indeed, a woman of rare beauty—her features delicately molded, her bearing graceful, and her voice as melodious as the song of a nightingale. The Parsee guide had not exaggerated; her education was evident in the purity of her English, spoken with an elegance that belied her recent ordeal.  

As the train whistled its imminent departure, Phileas Fogg, ever precise, handed the guide the exact sum agreed upon. Passepartout, however, shifted uneasily, his brow furrowed. 'Surely,' he thought, 'the man deserves more for his courage!' The risk the guide had taken weighed heavily on the valet’s mind—capture by the priests would mean a fate too grim to contemplate.  

Then came the question of Kiouni. The elephant, noble and costly, stood patiently beside them. Fogg, without hesitation, turned to the guide. 'The beast is yours,' he declared. 'A token of gratitude for services beyond mere payment.' The Parsee’s eyes widened in disbelief before joy overtook him—such a gift was fortune itself! Passepartout, delighted, rushed forward with sugar lumps, offering a fond farewell. Kiouni, as if understanding, curled his trunk around the valet, lifting him gently before setting him back down with an almost affectionate care.  

And so, with the matter settled, the party boarded the train, leaving behind the valley of the Ganges—unseen, unadmired, as Fogg’s singular focus pressed ever onward."
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When the Rajah of Bundelcund died, the beautiful Aouda was forced into the cruel practice of *sati*, expected to perish on her husband’s funeral pyre. Rescued by Phileas Fogg and Passepartout during their journey across India, she was at first deeply traumatized, her spirit broken by the horrors she had endured. The priests of Pillaji, who had once held her in thrall with their rigid doctrines and threats of divine wrath, had instilled in her a fear so profound that even in freedom, she struggled to reclaim her identity.  

Yet, as the days passed aboard the *Mongolia*, the gentle care of her rescuers began to work a quiet transformation. Phileas Fogg, though reserved, treated her with unwavering respect, while Passepartout’s cheerful nature brought warmth to her wounded heart. The farther they traveled from the shores of India, the more the oppressive shadow of the priests seemed to fade. Slowly, the terror in her eyes softened, replaced by a quiet wonder at the kindness she had found.  

By the time they reached Hong Kong, Aouda had begun to regain her natural grace. The softness of her voice, once stifled by fear, returned, and she spoke with a gentle confidence that had long been absent. Her eyes, which had once reflected only sorrow, now shone with the luminous depth of her true spirit—warm, intelligent, and full of quiet strength. She was no longer the trembling victim of a cruel fate but a woman rediscovering her own dignity.  

Fogg, ever observant though seldom expressive, noted the change with silent approval. Passepartout, ever the optimist, declared that Madame Aouda was blooming like a lotus after the rains. Indeed, the transformation was remarkable. The chains of superstition and dread that had bound her were loosening with each passing mile, and in their place grew a quiet resilience.  

By the time the group reached Yokohama, Aouda had fully emerged from the shadow of her past. She moved with the elegance of her noble upbringing, her mind sharp and her compassion undimmed. The priests of Pillaji had sought to extinguish her spirit, but in the company of true gentlemen—men who valued her life and freedom—she had found herself again.  

And so, as the journey continued, Aouda became not merely a passenger in Fogg’s audacious wager but a vital presence in their little band. Her gratitude for her rescue had deepened into genuine affection, and though she did not yet realize it, her fate was becoming inextricably linked with that of the unflappable Englishman who had saved her. The soft Indian expression in her eyes now held not only the memory of suffering but the quiet hope of a future reborn.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the text segment corresponding to the given metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**CHAPTER XIV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DESCENDS THE WHOLE LENGTH OF THE BEAUTIFUL VALLEY OF THE GANGES WITHOUT EVER THINKING OF SEEING IT**  

Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Then, as her thoughts reverted to the scene of the suttee, and she contemplated the surrounding danger, she shuddered with terror.  

Phileas Fogg understood what was passing in her mind, and offered, in order to reassure her, to escort her to Hong Kong, where she might remain safely until the affair blew over.  

She accepted the offer gratefully, for there resided at Hong Kong one of her relatives, a Parsee merchant, one of the most important in that city, which is wholly English, though occupying an island on the Chinese coast.  

At half-past twelve the train stopped at Benares. The Brahmin legends assert that this city is built on the site of the ancient Casi, which, like Mahomet’s tomb, was once suspended between heaven and earth; though the Benares of to-day, which the Orientalists call the Athens of India, stands quite unpoetically on the solid earth. Passepartout caught glimpses of its brick houses and clay huts, giving it an extremely desolate aspect, as the train crossed it.  

Sir Francis Cromarty stopped here, the troops he was rejoining being encamped some miles northward of the city. He bade adieu to Phileas Fogg, wishing him all success, and expressing the hope that he would come that way again in a less original but more profitable fashion. Mr. Fogg lightly pressed him by the hand. The parting of Aouda, who did not forget what she owed to Sir Francis, betrayed more warmth; and, as for Passepartout, he received a hearty shake of the hand from the gallant general.  

---

Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Overcome with emotion, she clasped her hands together, her delicate fingers trembling as she bowed her head in humble acknowledgment. The horrors of the suttee still haunted her, and the kindness of these strangers—Phileas Fogg, Passepartout, and Sir Francis Cromarty—had snatched her from the jaws of death.  

Passepartout, ever warm-hearted, beamed at her, his round face alight with satisfaction. "There, there, mademoiselle," he said cheerfully, "no need for tears! You're safe now, and that's what matters."  

Phileas Fogg, though as composed as ever, inclined his head slightly, his expression unreadable. Yet, in the depths of his gray eyes, there was a flicker of something—perhaps satisfaction at having righted a wrong. Sir Francis Cromarty, the gallant colonel, cleared his throat and offered his handkerchief, murmuring reassurances in his deep, steady voice.  

Aouda, though still shaken, felt a glimmer of hope. These men had risked much for her sake, and she vowed silently to prove herself worthy of their sacrifice. As the train rumbled onward, carrying them farther from the horrors of her past, she allowed herself, for the first time in many days, to believe in the possibility of a new beginning.

events.text_segment:
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. Through the windows of their carriage the travellers had glimpses of the diversified landscape of Behar, with its mountains clothed in verdure, its fields of barley, wheat, and corn, its jungles peopled with green alligators, its neat villages, and its still thickly-leaved forests. Elephants were bathing in the waters of the sacred river, and groups of Indians, despite the advanced season and chilly air, were performing solemnly their pious ablutions. These were fervent Brahmins, the bitterest foes of Buddhism, their deities being Vishnu, the solar god, Shiva, the divine impersonation of natural forces, and Brahma, the supreme ruler of priests and legislators. What would these divinities think of India, anglicised as it is to-day, with steamers whistling and scudding along the Ganges, frightening the gulls which float upon its surface, the turtles swarming along its banks, and the faithful dwelling upon its borders?
The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash, save when the steam concealed it fitfully from the view; the travellers could scarcely discern the fort of Chupenie, twenty miles south-westward from Benares, the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar; or Ghazipur and its famous rose-water factories; or the tomb of Lord Cornwallis, rising on the left bank of the Ganges; the fortified town of Buxar, or Patna, a large manufacturing and trading-place, where is held the principal opium market of India; or Monghir, a more than European town, for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham, with its iron foundries, edgetool factories, and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward.
Night came on; the train passed on at full speed, in the midst of the roaring of the tigers, bears, and wolves which fled before the locomotive; and the marvels of Bengal, Golconda ruined Gour, Murshedabad, the ancient capital, Burdwan, Hugly, and the French town of Chandernagor, where Passepartout would have been proud to see his country’s flag flying, were hidden from their view in the darkness.
Calcutta was reached at seven in the morning, and the packet left for Hong Kong at noon; so that Phileas Fogg had five hours before him.
According to his journal, he was due at Calcutta on the 25th of October, and that was the exact date of his actual arrival. He was therefore neither behind-hand nor ahead of time. The two days gained between London and Bombay had been lost, as has been seen, in the journey across India. But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.

**text_segment**:  
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. Through the windows of their carriage the travellers had glimpses of the diversified landscape of Behar, with its mountains clothed in verdure, its fields of barley, wheat, and corn, its jungles peopled with green alligators, its neat villages, and its still thickly-leaved forests. Elephants were bathing in the waters of the sacred river, and groups of Indians, despite the advanced season and chilly air, were performing solemnly their pious ablutions. These were fervent Brahmins, the bitterest foes of Buddhism, their deities being Vishnu, the solar god, Shiva, the divine impersonation of natural forces, and Brahma, the supreme ruler of priests and legislators. What would these divinities think of India, anglicised as it is to-day, with steamers whistling and scaring the birds that float upon the Ganges, with the noise of the locomotive frightening the sacred crocodiles basking on its banks, and the whole country traversed by that iron way, which, more than the pagodas and mosques, seems to bring the ancient land of the Brahmins under the dominion of the modern spirit?  

The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash, save when the steam concealed it fitfully from the view; the travellers could scarcely discern the fort of Chupenie, twenty miles south-westward from Benares, the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar; or Ghazipur and its famous rose-water factories; or the tomb of Lord Cornwallis, rising on the left bank of the Ganges; the fortified town of Buxar, or Patna, a large manufacturing and trading-place, where the principal opium market is held; or Monghir, a more than European town, for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham, with its iron foundries, edge-tool factories, and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward.  

Night came on; the train passed on at full speed, in the midst of the roaring of the tigers, bears, and wolves which fled before the locomotive; and the marvels of Bengal, Golconda, ruined Gour, Murshedabad, the ancient capital, Burdwan, Hugly, and the French town of Chandernagor, where Passepartout would have been proud to see his country’s flag flying, were hidden from their view in the darkness.  

Calcutta was reached at seven in the morning, and the packet left for Hong Kong at noon; so that Phileas Fogg had five hours before him.  

According to his journal, he was due at Calcutta on the 25th of October, and that date found him punctual to his appointment. The two days gained between London and Bombay had been lost, as we have seen, in the journey across India; but it is to be supposed that Phileas Fogg did not regret them.  

--- 

This passage matches the chapter title, characters, and detailed summary provided, capturing Fogg's journey through the Ganges valley with observations of the landscape, religious practices, and industrial changes, culminating in his timely arrival in Calcutta.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. The broad, sluggish river wound its way through the fertile plains, its waters reflecting the golden hues of the setting sun. On either side, the landscape was a patchwork of emerald-green rice fields and clusters of palm trees, their fronds swaying gently in the warm breeze. Here and there, small villages dotted the countryside, their mud-brick huts and thatched roofs blending seamlessly into the earth. The air was thick with the scent of damp soil and blooming flowers, a testament to the land’s unyielding fertility.  

As the train rumbled onward, Phileas Fogg gazed out the window with his usual calm detachment, though the scene outside was one of unparalleled beauty. To him, the journey was but a means to an end—a calculated step in his meticulous plan to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. Yet even he could not entirely ignore the timeless grandeur of the Ganges, a river revered as sacred by millions. Along its banks, pilgrims bathed in its waters, their prayers rising like incense into the evening air. Fishermen cast their nets with practiced ease, while women in brightly colored saris filled earthen pots with water, their movements graceful and unhurried.  

Passepartout, ever the curious observer, pressed his face against the glass, marveling at the sights. To him, India was a land of endless fascination—its vibrant colors, its rich aromas, its teeming life. He longed to step off the train and lose himself in the bustling bazaars, to taste the spicy curries and hear the lilting melodies of street musicians. But time, as his master so often reminded him, was of the essence.  

The train soon left the river behind, plunging into the dense jungles of central India. The dense foliage pressed close to the tracks, and the occasional cry of a distant animal sent a shiver down Passepartout’s spine. Yet even here, signs of human habitation persisted—a lone farmer tending his field, a group of children waving excitedly as the train roared past.  

As night fell, the rhythmic clatter of the wheels lulled many passengers to sleep. But Fogg remained awake, his pocket watch in hand, counting the minutes with unwavering precision. The journey was far from over, and every second brought him closer to his goal—or further from it, should fortune prove unkind.  

Outside, the moon cast its silvery light over the landscape, transforming the world into a realm of shadows and whispers. Somewhere in the distance, a jackal howled, its mournful cry echoing through the stillness. The train pressed on, a mechanical beast cutting through the heart of an ancient land, carrying its passengers ever forward into the unknown.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XV. IN WHICH THE BAG OF BANKNOTES DISGORGES SOME THOUSANDS OF POUNDS MORE

events.title: Arrival in Calcutta and Immediate Arrest
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout arrive at the Calcutta train station.
Fogg intends to immediately board the Hong Kong steamer to ensure Aouda's safety.
A policeman approaches Fogg, confirms his identity and that Passepartout is his servant, and instructs them both to follow him.
Fogg displays no surprise, respecting the law, while Passepartout's attempt to question is silenced by the policeman and Fogg's signal.
Aouda is permitted to accompany them.
They are transported in a four-wheeled carriage (palkigahri) through contrasting parts of the city: the poor 'black town' and the affluent 'European town'.
No one speaks during the twenty-minute journey.
They arrive at a modest building, revealed to be a place of detention.
The policeman escorts them into a room with barred windows, informing them they will appear before Judge Obadiah soon.
The policeman leaves, locking the door behind him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then retired, and closed the door.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Phileas Fogg intended to proceed at once to the Hong Kong steamer, in order to get Aouda comfortably settled for the voyage. He was unwilling to leave her while they were still on dangerous ground.
Just as he was leaving the station a policeman came up to him, and said, “Mr. Phileas Fogg?”
“I am he.”
“Is this man your servant?” added the policeman, pointing to Passepartout.
“Yes.”
“Be so good, both of you, as to follow me.”
Mr. Fogg betrayed no surprise whatever. The policeman was a representative of the law, and law is sacred to an Englishman. Passepartout tried to reason about the matter, but the policeman tapped him with his stick, and Mr. Fogg made him a signal to obey.
“May this young lady go with us?” asked he.
“She may,” replied the policeman.
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout were conducted to a palkigahri, a sort of four-wheeled carriage, drawn by two horses, in which they took their places and were driven away. No one spoke during the twenty minutes which elapsed before they reached their destination. They first passed through the “black town,” with its narrow streets, its miserable, dirty huts, and squalid population; then through the “European town,” which presented a relief in its bright brick mansions, shaded by coconut-trees and bristling with masts, where, although it was early morning, elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing back and forth.
The carriage stopped before a modest-looking house, which, however, did not have the appearance of a private mansion. The policeman having requested his prisoners—for so, truly, they might be called—to descend, conducted them into a room with barred windows, and said: “You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half-past eight.”
He then retired, and closed the door.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. The trio found themselves amidst the bustling crowds of yet another exotic locale, their journey around the world continuing at its relentless pace.  

As they stepped onto the platform, the air was thick with the mingled scents of spices, coal smoke, and the faint brine of a distant sea. Passepartout, ever eager, scanned the surroundings for any sign of their next connection, while Phileas Fogg remained as composed as ever, his watch in hand, calculating the minutes they had to spare.  

Aouda, though weary from the journey, maintained her quiet dignity, her eyes reflecting both curiosity and gratitude for Fogg’s unwavering courtesy. The station was alive with activity—vendors hawking their wares, porters rushing to and fro with luggage, and travelers of all nations hurrying to their destinations.  

Fogg, ever precise, turned to Passepartout. "We have exactly twenty-seven minutes before our next departure. See to it that our luggage is transferred without delay."  

"At once, monsieur!" Passepartout replied, darting off to secure their belongings.  

As they waited, Aouda glanced at Fogg, her voice soft but steady. "Mr. Fogg, your kindness knows no bounds. I cannot thank you enough for all you have done."  

Fogg, though not one for sentiment, inclined his head slightly. "It is nothing, madam. A matter of duty and honor."  

Just then, a commotion erupted nearby—a group of local officials seemed to be arguing with a frantic traveler. Passepartout, ever drawn to excitement, edged closer, but Fogg’s firm hand on his shoulder held him back.  

"We have no time for distractions," Fogg reminded him. "Our schedule is absolute."  

With a sigh, Passepartout nodded, and as the whistle of their next train sounded, the trio boarded once more, their extraordinary voyage carrying them ever forward against the ticking clock of fate.

events.title: Reactions to Imprisonment and Fogg's Resolve
detailed_summary: Passepartout exclaims in dismay that they are prisoners.
Aouda, emotional but trying to hide it, tells Fogg he should abandon her, blaming herself for his predicament.
Fogg calmly dismisses her suggestion as impossible, stating he wouldn't be arrested for preventing a suttee and that there must be a mistake.
He reaffirms his commitment to escorting Aouda to Hong Kong.
Passepartout nervously points out the steamer departs at noon.
Fogg confidently assures him they will be on board by noon.
His certainty impresses Passepartout, who mutters agreement, though he remains deeply uneasy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But he was by no means reassured.

events.text_segment:
“Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
Aouda, with an emotion she tried to conceal, said to Mr. Fogg: “Sir, you must leave me to my fate! It is on my account that you receive this treatment, it is for having saved me!”
Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that it was impossible. It was quite unlikely that he should be arrested for preventing a suttee. The complainants would not dare present themselves with such a charge. There was some mistake. Moreover, he would not, in any event, abandon Aouda, but would escort her to Hong Kong.
“But the steamer leaves at noon!” observed Passepartout, nervously.
“We shall be on board by noon,” replied his master, placidly.
It was said so positively that Passepartout could not help muttering to himself, “Parbleu that’s certain! Before noon we shall be on board.” But he was by no means reassured.

**text_segment**:  

“Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.  

Aouda, turning to Mr. Fogg with an emotion she was unable to suppress, said:  

“Sir, you must abandon me! It is on my account that you are pursued! It is because you saved me!”  

Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that it was impossible. It was not possible that he should be arrested for preventing a suttee. The complainants would not dare present themselves. There was some mistake.  

At all events, he would not abandon the young woman, but would escort her to Hong Kong.  

“But the steamer leaves at noon!” observed Passepartout, nervously.  

“We shall be on board by noon,” replied the impassible gentleman.  

It was said so positively that Passepartout could not help muttering to himself:  

“Parbleu! that’s certain! Before noon we shall be on board.” But he was by no means reassured.  

---

events.title: Court Appearance and Initial Proceedings
detailed_summary: At half-past eight, the policeman returns and leads them to an adjacent courtroom, already filled with Europeans and natives.
Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout sit on a bench opposite the magistrate's and clerk's desks.
Judge Obadiah, a portly man, enters with his clerk, Oysterpuff.
The judge mistakenly puts on the clerk's wig before realizing his error.
He questions how a judge can deliver a wise sentence in a clerk's wig, and they exchange headpieces.
Passepartout grows increasingly anxious as he watches the clock.
The judge calls the first case, and Oysterpuff confirms the presence of Phileas Fogg and Passepartout.
The judge mentions they have been sought for two days.
Passepartout impatiently asks about the charges.
Fogg asserts his rights as an English subject.

events.text_segment:
At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. It was evidently a court-room, and a crowd of Europeans and natives already occupied the rear of the apartment.
Mr. Fogg and his two companions took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and his clerk. Immediately after, Judge Obadiah, a fat, round man, followed by the clerk, entered. He proceeded to take down a wig which was hanging on a nail, and put it hurriedly on his head.
“The first case,” said he. Then, putting his hand to his head, he exclaimed, “Heh! This is not my wig!”
“No, your worship,” returned the clerk, “it is mine.”
“My dear Mr. Oysterpuff, how can a judge give a wise sentence in a clerk’s wig?”
The wigs were exchanged.
Passepartout was getting nervous, for the hands on the face of the big clock over the judge seemed to go around with terrible rapidity.
“The first case,” repeated Judge Obadiah.
“Phileas Fogg?” demanded Oysterpuff.
“I am here,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“Passepartout?”
“Present,” responded Passepartout.
“Good,” said the judge. “You have been looked for, prisoners, for two days on the trains from Bombay.”
“But of what are we accused?” asked Passepartout, impatiently.
“You are about to be informed.”
“I am an English subject, sir,” said Mr. Fogg, “and I have the right—”
“Have you been ill-treated?”
“Not at all.”
“Very well; let the complainants come in.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. The room was dimly lit, its high ceilings echoing the murmurs of officials shuffling papers. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, adjusted his cravat as he stepped forward, while Passepartout, wide-eyed, clutched his hat nervously.  

A stern-faced magistrate sat behind a heavy oak desk, his spectacles perched low on his nose as he scrutinized the documents before him. The air was thick with tension, though Fogg betrayed no hint of unease.  

"You are accused of illegally entering Indian soil under false pretenses," the magistrate intoned, his voice cold and measured.  

Fogg, unruffled, replied, "I assure you, sir, there has been a misunderstanding. My passport is in perfect order."  

Passepartout, unable to contain himself, burst out, "It’s all my fault! I didn’t know the temple was forbidden!"  

The magistrate’s gaze flickered between them before he sighed and leaned back in his chair. "Be that as it may, the law is clear. Bail is set at two thousand pounds."  

Without hesitation, Fogg drew a checkbook from his coat. "Very well. I shall pay at once."  

The magistrate’s eyebrows rose slightly, but he said nothing as the transaction was completed. Within minutes, Fogg and Passepartout were free—though their journey had now grown even more precarious. Time was slipping away, and every delay threatened Fogg’s wager. Yet, as always, the unflappable Englishman showed no sign of doubt.

events.title: The Accusation and Confusion Over the Crime
detailed_summary: Three Indian priests enter the courtroom.
Passepartout mutters that these are the men who intended to sacrifice Aouda.
The priests stand before the judge, and the clerk reads a charge of sacrilege against Fogg and Passepartout.
They are accused of violating a sacred Brahmin temple.
The judge asks Fogg if he understands the charge.
Fogg, checking his watch, admits to the charge.
He demands the priests, in turn, admit what they were planning at the Pillaji pagoda.
The priests appear confused by Fogg's statement.
Passepartout interjects, specifying the pagoda where the priests were about to burn their victim.
The judge and priests are stunned.
Judge Obadiah clarifies the charge relates not to Pillaji, but to the Malabar Hill pagoda in Bombay.
The clerk produces a pair of shoes as evidence, stating they are the desecrator's shoes left behind.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Whereupon he placed a pair of shoes on his desk.

events.text_segment:
A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered.
“That’s it,” muttered Passepartout; “these are the rogues who were going to burn our young lady.”
The priests took their places in front of the judge, and the clerk proceeded to read in a loud voice a complaint of sacrilege against Phileas Fogg and his servant, who were accused of having violated a place held consecrated by the Brahmin religion.
“You hear the charge?” asked the judge.
“Yes, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg, consulting his watch, “and I admit it.”
“You admit it?”
“I admit it, and I wish to hear these priests admit, in their turn, what they were going to do at the pagoda of Pillaji.”
The priests looked at each other; they did not seem to understand what was said.
“Yes,” cried Passepartout, warmly; “at the pagoda of Pillaji, where they were on the point of burning their victim.”
The judge stared with astonishment, and the priests were stupefied.
“What victim?” said Judge Obadiah. “Burn whom? In Bombay itself?”
“Bombay?” cried Passepartout.
“Certainly. We are not talking of the pagoda of Pillaji, but of the pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay.”
“And as a proof,” added the clerk, “here are the desecrator’s very shoes, which he left behind him.”
Whereupon he placed a pair of shoes on his desk.

A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered. Their faces were solemn, their robes flowing, and their eyes burning with quiet intensity. The courtroom fell into a hushed silence as they approached the bench, their measured steps echoing against the wooden floor.  

The leader of the three, a tall man with a long white beard, stepped forward and bowed deeply before the judge. "Your Honor," he began in a voice both firm and reverent, "we come before you as representatives of the sacred temple of Kali. A great wrong has been committed—one that demands justice."  

The judge leaned forward, his curiosity piqued. "Speak, then. What is this wrong you accuse the prisoner of committing?"  

The priest’s gaze flickered toward Phileas Fogg, who stood composed as ever, though Passepartout fidgeted nervously beside him. "This man," the priest declared, pointing an accusing finger at Passepartout, "has defiled our holiest of grounds. He trespassed upon the temple during sacred rites, his very presence an insult to the goddess."  

A murmur rippled through the courtroom. Passepartout’s face paled, but Fogg remained unmoved, his expression as calm as if he were merely reviewing a railway timetable. The judge stroked his chin thoughtfully. "And what proof do you bring of this offense?"  

The priests exchanged glances before the eldest produced a small, intricately carved idol from within his robes. "This," he said, holding it aloft, "was found in his possession."  

The courtroom erupted in gasps. The trial had taken a most unexpected turn.

events.title: Passepartout's Blunder and Fix's Machinations Revealed
detailed_summary: Passepartout impulsively cries out, "My shoes!", realizing his mistake too late.
Both master and servant are confused, having forgotten the incident at the Bombay pagoda, which is the cause of their current detention in Calcutta.
The narrative reveals Detective Fix's role in the arrest.
