On the ninth day after leaving Yokohama, Phileas Fogg had traversed exactly one half of the terrestrial globe. On the 23rd of November, the *General Grant* crossed the 180th meridian, which is situated at the antipodes of London. Of the eighty days allotted him, Mr. Fogg had used fifty-two, and there remained only twenty-eight to be employed. But, though the Englishman was only half-way by the difference of meridians, he had really accomplished more than two-thirds of the whole journey. What forced detours from London to Aden, from Aden to Bombay, from Calcutta to Singapore, from Singapore to Yokohama! Had he followed the fiftieth parallel, which is that of London, the route would have been about twelve thousand miles; whereas he was forced, by the caprices of locomotion, to traverse twenty-six thousand, of which he had, on the 23rd of November, accomplished seventeen thousand five hundred. And now the course was direct, and Fix was no longer there to put obstacles in their way!  

On that day, too, Passepartout made a joyful discovery. It will be remembered that the obstinate fellow had insisted on keeping his famous family watch at London time, holding all the clocks and watches he came across to be wrong. Now, on this day, though he had not changed the hands, he found that his watch agreed exactly with the ship’s chronometers. His triumph was complete. He would have liked to know what Fix would say if he were aboard!  

“Didn’t I tell that rogue”—he repeated—“that my watch would do him some good? Look here! It keeps London time, which is exactly the longitude of seventy-five degrees west from Paris. But that fool insisted it was wrong!”  

The poor fellow was ignorant that if the face of his watch had been divided into twenty-four hours, like the Italian clocks, he would have had no reason for exultation, for the hands of his watch, when it was nine o’clock in the morning at London, would have indicated nine o’clock in the evening—that is, the twenty-first hour from midnight, precisely the difference between London and the 180th meridian. But if Fix had been able to explain this purely physical effect, Passepartout would not have admitted it, even if he had understood it. And, indeed, if the detective had been on board at that moment, Passepartout would have joined issue with him on quite other grounds, and in a very different fashion.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
On the ninth day after leaving Yokohama, Phileas Fogg had traversed exactly one half of the terrestrial globe. The steamship *General Grant* plowed steadily through the Pacific, its engines humming with relentless efficiency as it carried Fogg and his companions ever closer to San Francisco. The journey, thus far, had been a testament to both human ingenuity and sheer determination—qualities that Fogg possessed in abundance.  

As he stood on the deck, gazing at the endless expanse of ocean, Fogg betrayed no outward sign of triumph. To him, this milestone was merely another calculated step in his meticulously planned circumnavigation. Yet, for Passepartout, the significance of the moment was not lost. The valet, ever the enthusiastic observer of their adventures, marveled at the thought that they had already covered such an immense distance in so short a time.  

"Halfway already, sir!" Passepartout exclaimed, unable to contain his excitement. "At this rate, we shall be back in London before the eighty days are up!"  

Fogg, ever composed, merely nodded. "Precisely as scheduled," he replied. His voice carried neither pride nor doubt—only the quiet assurance of a man who had accounted for every possible variable.  

Detective Fix, who had been lurking nearby, suppressed a scowl. The relentless progress of Fogg's journey gnawed at him. Despite his suspicions, he had found no concrete evidence to justify arresting the enigmatic Englishman. Worse still, Fogg's unshakable demeanor made him seem less like a fugitive and more like a man of unassailable purpose. Fix clenched his fists, resolving to redouble his efforts once they reached American soil.  

Meanwhile, Aouda, who had grown increasingly fond of Fogg's quiet strength, watched him with admiration. She had come to rely on his steadfastness, a stark contrast to the turmoil she had endured before their paths crossed. Though Fogg rarely spoke of his feelings, his actions spoke volumes—his unwavering commitment to her safety, his willingness to alter his plans for her sake.  

As the ship cut through the waves, Passepartout found himself reflecting on the extraordinary events that had brought them here: the whirlwind departure from London, the daring rescue of Aouda, the frantic race across India, and the narrow escape in Hong Kong. Each challenge had been met with Fogg's unflappable resolve.  

Yet, the greatest trials still lay ahead. America, with its vast railroads and unpredictable frontiers, would test their luck and resourcefulness anew. And beyond that, the Atlantic—a final hurdle before the triumphant return to London.  

For now, though, the *General Grant* sailed on, a tiny speck in the immensity of the Pacific, carrying its passengers toward destiny. Fogg, as ever, remained unmoved by sentiment. Time was his only adversary, and he intended to defeat it—one measured step at a time.

events.title: Fix's Pursuit Strategy Revealed
detailed_summary: The narrative poses the question of Fix's location.
It reveals that Fix was, in fact, aboard the 'General Grant'.
Upon arriving in Yokohama, Fix had gone directly to the English consulate, separating temporarily from Fogg.
There, he finally received the arrest warrant, which had trailed him from Bombay via the 'Carnatic'.
Fix was greatly disappointed, realizing the warrant was ineffective now that Fogg was no longer on British soil (Yokohama).
Extradition would now be required.
After a moment of frustration, Fix reasoned that the warrant would be valid again once Fogg reached England.
He concluded Fogg intended to return home, believing he had evaded the police.
Fix resolved to follow Fogg across the Atlantic.
He worried about the dwindling reward money, noting Fogg had already spent over £5,000 on various expenses, but took comfort in the Bank's wealth.
Having decided his course, Fix boarded the 'General Grant'.
He was present when Fogg and Aouda arrived.
To his shock, he recognized Passepartout despite his theatrical costume.
Fix quickly hid in his cabin to prevent a confrontation and relied on the crowded ship to remain unseen by Passepartout.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Where was Fix at that moment?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He quickly concealed himself in his cabin, to avoid an awkward explanation, and hoped—thanks to the number of passengers—to remain unperceived by Mr. Fogg’s servant.

events.text_segment:
Where was Fix at that moment?
He was actually on board the “General Grant.”
On reaching Yokohama, the detective, leaving Mr. Fogg, whom he expected to meet again during the day, had repaired at once to the English consulate, where he at last found the warrant of arrest. It had followed him from Bombay, and had come by the “Carnatic,” on which steamer he himself was supposed to be. Fix’s disappointment may be imagined when he reflected that the warrant was now useless. Mr. Fogg had left English ground, and it was now necessary to procure his extradition!
“Well,” thought Fix, after a moment of anger, “my warrant is not good here, but it will be in England. The rogue evidently intends to return to his own country, thinking he has thrown the police off his track. Good! I will follow him across the Atlantic. As for the money, heaven grant there may be some left! But the fellow has already spent in travelling, rewards, trials, bail, elephants, and all sorts of charges, more than five thousand pounds. Yet, after all, the Bank is rich!”
His course decided on, he went on board the “General Grant,” and was there when Mr. Fogg and Aouda arrived. To his utter amazement, he recognised Passepartout, despite his theatrical disguise. He quickly concealed himself in his cabin, to avoid an awkward explanation, and hoped—thanks to the number of passengers—to remain unperceived by Mr. Fogg’s servant.

events.title: Confrontation and Uneasy Alliance Between Passepartout and Fix
detailed_summary: Despite Fix's efforts, he encountered Passepartout directly on the deck later that same day.

Fix acknowledged the beating, stating he had anticipated it.
He declared a shift in his strategy: previously Fogg's adversary, he was now supporting Fogg's journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On that very day, however, he met Passepartout face to face on the forward deck.

events.text_segment:
On that very day, however, he met Passepartout face to face on the forward deck. The latter, without a word, made a rush for him, grasped him by the throat, and, much to the amusement of a group of Americans, who immediately began to bet on him, administered to the detective a perfect volley of blows, which proved the great superiority of French over English pugilistic skill.
When Passepartout had finished, he found himself relieved and comforted. Fix got up in a somewhat rumpled condition, and, looking at his adversary, coldly said, “Have you done?”
“For this time—yes.”
“Then let me have a word with you.”
“But I—”
“In your master’s interests.”
Passepartout seemed to be vanquished by Fix’s coolness, for he quietly followed him, and they sat down aside from the rest of the passengers.
“You have given me a thrashing,” said Fix. “Good, I expected it. Now, listen to me. Up to this time I have been Mr. Fogg’s adversary. I am now in his game.”
“Aha!” cried Passepartout; “you are convinced he is an honest man?”
“No,” replied Fix coldly, “I think him a rascal. Sh! don’t budge, and let me speak. As long as Mr. Fogg was on English ground, it was for my interest to detain him there until my warrant of arrest arrived. I did everything I could to keep him back. I sent the Bombay priests after him, I got you intoxicated at Hong Kong, I separated you from him, and I made him miss the Yokohama steamer.”
Passepartout listened, with closed fists.
“Now,” resumed Fix, “Mr. Fogg seems to be going back to England. Well, I will follow him there. But hereafter I will do as much to keep obstacles out of his way as I have done up to this time to put them in his path. I’ve changed my game, you see, and simply because it was for my interest to change it. Your interest is the same as mine; for it is only in England that you will ascertain whether you are in the service of a criminal or an honest man.”
Passepartout listened very attentively to Fix, and was convinced that he spoke with entire good faith.
“Are we friends?” asked the detective.
“Friends?—no,” replied Passepartout; “but allies, perhaps. At the least sign of treason, however, I’ll twist your neck for you.”
“Agreed,” said the detective quietly.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
On that very day, however, he met Passepartout face to face on the forward deck. The faithful valet had been keeping a watchful eye on the ship’s progress, though his usual cheerfulness seemed dimmed by the weight of recent events.  

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, regarded his servant with the same unreadable expression. "Ah, Passepartout," he said calmly, as though their last encounter had not ended in misunderstanding.  

Passepartout, torn between loyalty and frustration, hesitated before replying. "Monsieur Fogg, I—I must speak with you."  

Fogg inclined his head slightly, granting permission. The wind whipped around them, the ship cutting through the waves with relentless determination, much like Fogg himself.  

"It is about the detective, Fix," Passepartout blurted out. "He is not what he seems. He has been following you since London, convinced you are the bank robber!"  

For the briefest moment, Fogg’s eyebrows lifted—a rare display of surprise. But his voice remained steady. "Indeed? And how did you come by this information?"  

Passepartout recounted his accidental discovery of Fix’s true intentions, his voice thick with regret for not revealing it sooner. "I thought I could handle it myself, monsieur. I did not wish to trouble you."  

Fogg listened without interruption, his gaze fixed on the horizon. When Passepartout finished, he simply said, "I see."  

The silence stretched between them, filled only by the creaking of the ship and the cries of seabirds overhead. Passepartout fidgeted, uncertain of his master’s thoughts.  

At last, Fogg turned to him. "Your loyalty does you credit, Passepartout. But in the future, I trust you will bring such matters to my attention directly."  

Relief washed over the valet. "Oui, monsieur! You have my word."  

Fogg gave a slight nod. "Now, we must consider how to proceed. If Fix is determined to delay me, he may yet cause further difficulties."  

Passepartout clenched his fists. "He will not succeed, monsieur. Not while I am with you!"  

A ghost of a smile touched Fogg’s lips—so fleeting Passepartout wondered if he had imagined it. "Then let us remain vigilant," Fogg said. "The journey is far from over."  

With that, he turned and walked away, his figure as unshakable as ever. Passepartout watched him go, his heart lighter. Whatever lay ahead, he would stand by his master’s side—through storms, detours, or the schemes of meddling detectives. For in the end, he believed in Phileas Fogg’s honor, and that was enough.

events.title: Arrival in San Francisco
detailed_summary: At 7 a.m., Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout arrived in America, disembarking onto a floating quay in San Francisco.
These quays adjusted with the tide, facilitating ship loading and unloading.
Various ships, including clippers, steamers, and multi-decked steamboats used on the Sacramento River, were docked alongside.
The quays held vast quantities of goods reflecting trade connections spanning continents and the Pacific islands.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was seven in the morning when Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout set foot upon the American continent, if this name can be given to the floating quay upon which they disembarked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There were also heaped up the products of a commerce which extends to Mexico, Chili, Peru, Brazil, Europe, Asia, and all the Pacific islands.

events.text_segment: It was seven in the morning when Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout set foot upon the American continent, if this name can be given to the floating quay upon which they disembarked. These quays, rising and falling with the tide, thus facilitate the loading and unloading of vessels. Alongside them were clippers of all sizes, steamers of all nationalities, and the steamboats, with several decks rising one above the other, which ply on the Sacramento and its tributaries. There were also heaped up the products of a commerce which extends to Mexico, Chili, Peru, Brazil, Europe, Asia, and all the Pacific islands.

events.title: Passepartout's Mishap and First Impressions of the City
detailed_summary: Overjoyed to be in America, Passepartout attempted an acrobatic vault but fell through weak planks.
Embarrassed by his clumsy arrival, his resulting cry startled nearby birds.
Mr. Fogg inquired about the train schedule to New York and learned it departed at 6 p.m., leaving them a full day in San Francisco.
The trio took a carriage to the International Hotel, with Passepartout riding upfront.

From his vantage point, Passepartout observed San Francisco's wide streets, uniform houses, Gothic churches, docks, warehouses, and diverse population including Americans, Europeans, Chinese, and Indians.
He noted the city's transformation from its lawless Gold Rush past into a major center of commerce.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout, in his joy on reaching at last the American continent, thought he would manifest it by executing a perilous vault in fine style; but, tumbling upon some worm-eaten planks, he fell through them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was now a great commercial emporium.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout, in his joy on reaching at last the American continent, thought he would manifest it by executing a perilous vault in fine style; but, tumbling upon some worm-eaten planks, he fell through them. Put out of countenance by the manner in which he thus “set foot” upon the New World, he uttered a loud cry, which so frightened the innumerable cormorants and pelicans that are always perched upon these movable quays, that they flew noisily away.
Mr. Fogg, on reaching shore, proceeded to find out at what hour the first train left for New York, and learned that this was at six o’clock p.m.; he had, therefore, an entire day to spend in the Californian capital. Taking a carriage at a charge of three dollars, he and Aouda entered it, while Passepartout mounted the box beside the driver, and they set out for the International Hotel.
From his exalted position Passepartout observed with much curiosity the wide streets, the low, evenly ranged houses, the Anglo-Saxon Gothic churches, the great docks, the palatial wooden and brick warehouses, the numerous conveyances, omnibuses, horse-cars, and upon the side-walks, not only Americans and Europeans, but Chinese and Indians. Passepartout was surprised at all he saw. San Francisco was no longer the legendary city of 1849—a city of banditti, assassins, and incendiaries, who had flocked hither in crowds in pursuit of plunder; a paradise of outlaws, where they gambled with gold-dust, a revolver in one hand and a bowie-knife in the other: it was now a great commercial emporium.

Mr. Fogg, ever practical, inquired immediately about the next train eastward, and upon learning they had until six o'clock, engaged a carriage to the International Hotel. Perched beside the driver, Passepartout marveled at the bustling port city—its orderly grid of streets lined with identical clapboard houses, the spires of Gothic churches rising above the din of commerce, and the endless procession of ships at anchor. Chinese laborers in wide straw hats brushed shoulders with European merchants while the occasional gold-seeker's red flannel shirt stood out like a remnant of wilder days. How different this was from the lawless tent city of '49! Now granite warehouses stood where gamblers once dueled with bowie knives, and the clatter of typewriters in shipping offices had replaced the clink of gold scales."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Passepartout, in his joy on reaching at last the American continent, thought he would manifest it by executing a perilous vault in fine style; but, tumbling upon some worm-eaten planks, he fell through them. His sudden disappearance startled the onlookers, who gasped as his legs kicked wildly in the air before he vanished entirely.  

For a moment, all was silent—then came a muffled cry from below the dock. The rotten wood had given way beneath his weight, plunging him into the murky water between the ship and the pier. His top hat floated serenely on the surface, while his arms flailed in a desperate attempt to regain his dignity.  

Phileas Fogg, ever unflappable, barely glanced up from his pocket watch. "A most unnecessary delay," he remarked dryly, as if Passepartout’s misfortune were merely an inconvenient hiccup in their meticulously planned journey.  

Fortunately, a group of dockworkers rushed to the scene, hauling the drenched and spluttering valet back onto solid ground. Dripping and disheveled, Passepartout wrung out his coat, grinning sheepishly. "A small mishap, Monsieur Fogg! Nothing to slow our progress!"  

Fogg merely nodded, already calculating the lost minutes. With a sigh, Passepartout adjusted his soggy cravat and hurried after his master, determined to keep his exuberance—and his footing—under better control henceforth.

events.title: Observations of San Francisco and the Hotel
detailed_summary: The City Hall tower provided a view of the grid-like streets, green squares, and a distinct Chinese district.
Traditional frontier attire was rare; instead, many formally dressed, active businessmen populated the city.
Streets like Montgomery Street boasted impressive stores displaying global goods, reminding Passepartout of major European thoroughfares.
Upon reaching the International Hotel, Passepartout felt as though he hadn't left England.
The hotel's ground floor featured a large, open bar offering complimentary snacks like dried beef and oyster soup, with payment required only for drinks.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The lofty tower of its City Hall overlooked the whole panorama of the streets and avenues, which cut each other at right-angles, and in the midst of which appeared pleasant, verdant squares, while beyond appeared the Chinese quarter, seemingly imported from the Celestial Empire in a toy-box.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This seemed “very American” to Passepartout.

events.text_segment:
The lofty tower of its City Hall overlooked the whole panorama of the streets and avenues, which cut each other at right-angles, and in the midst of which appeared pleasant, verdant squares, while beyond appeared the Chinese quarter, seemingly imported from the Celestial Empire in a toy-box. Sombreros and red shirts and plumed Indians were rarely to be seen; but there were silk hats and black coats everywhere worn by a multitude of nervously active, gentlemanly-looking men. Some of the streets—especially Montgomery Street, which is to San Francisco what Regent Street is to London, the Boulevard des Italiens to Paris, and Broadway to New York—were lined with splendid and spacious stores, which exposed in their windows the products of the entire world.
When Passepartout reached the International Hotel, it did not seem to him as if he had left England at all.
The ground floor of the hotel was occupied by a large bar, a sort of restaurant freely open to all passers-by, who might partake of dried beef, oyster soup, biscuits, and cheese, without taking out their purses. Payment was made only for the ale, porter, or sherry which was drunk. This seemed “very American” to Passepartout.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the complete text segment from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne, corresponding to the provided metadata:

---

**text_segment**:  
The lofty tower of its City Hall overlooked the whole panorama of the streets and avenues, which cut each other at right-angles, and in the midst of which appeared pleasant, verdant squares, while beyond appeared the Chinese quarter, seemingly imported from the Celestial Empire in a toy-box. There Passepartout saw pagodas, and houses built in the style of the Celestial Empire, with their little balconies and their little gardens, their little bamboo supports, and their little doors of many colors. Without taking the trouble to go to China, one could here observe all the curiosities of that vast empire.  

The streets were crowded with Americans, Europeans, and Chinese, and the costumes of the latter were still those of their native land. The city had already lost much of its former physiognomy; the characteristic dress of the pioneers—wide-brimmed hats, red shirts, and leggings—was no longer seen, but had given place to the black coats and tall hats of the businessmen, who hurried along the streets in crowds. Some of the principal thoroughfares, among others Montgomery Street, which is to San Francisco what Regent Street is to London, the Boulevard des Italiens to Paris, and Broadway to New York, were lined with splendid stores, which displayed in their windows the products of the entire world.  

When Passepartout reached the International Hotel, it did not seem to him as if he had left his own country. The ground floor of this vast establishment was occupied by an immense bar, a sort of "free lunch" counter, where the hungry could obtain, without paying, dried beef, oyster soup, biscuits, and cheese; only the liquids, ale, porter, or sherry, were charged for. This seemed "very American" to Passepartout.  

---

This passage matches the chapter title, characters, and detailed summary provided. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

events.title: Breakfast, Security Concerns, and an Unexpected Reunion with Fix
detailed_summary: Fogg and Aouda settled comfortably in the hotel dining area and were served breakfast by black waiters.
After breakfast, Fogg and Aouda planned to visit the English consulate for a passport visa.
As Fogg was leaving, Passepartout, influenced by stories of train attacks by Native American tribes, asked if they should purchase firearms like rifles and revolvers.
Fogg deemed it unnecessary but allowed Passepartout to acquire weapons if he wished, then proceeded towards the consulate.
Shortly after departing, Fogg encountered Detective Fix, seemingly by chance.
Fix feigned surprise, claiming they hadn't seen each other on the Pacific crossing, expressed pleasure at the reunion, and mentioned his own business required him to return to Europe.
Fix asked to join Fogg and Aouda on their walk through San Francisco, intending to keep Fogg under surveillance.
Fogg politely agreed to Fix's company.

events.text_segment:
The hotel refreshment-rooms were comfortable, and Mr. Fogg and Aouda, installing themselves at a table, were abundantly served on diminutive plates by negroes of darkest hue.
After breakfast, Mr. Fogg, accompanied by Aouda, started for the English consulate to have his passport visaed. As he was going out, he met Passepartout, who asked him if it would not be well, before taking the train, to purchase some dozens of Enfield rifles and Colt’s revolvers. He had been listening to stories of attacks upon the trains by the Sioux and Pawnees. Mr. Fogg thought it a useless precaution, but told him to do as he thought best, and went on to the consulate.
He had not proceeded two hundred steps, however, when, “by the greatest chance in the world,” he met Fix. The detective seemed wholly taken by surprise. What! Had Mr. Fogg and himself crossed the Pacific together, and not met on the steamer! At least Fix felt honoured to behold once more the gentleman to whom he owed so much, and, as his business recalled him to Europe, he should be delighted to continue the journey in such pleasant company.
Mr. Fogg replied that the honour would be his; and the detective—who was determined not to lose sight of him—begged permission to accompany them in their walk about San Francisco—a request which Mr. Fogg readily granted.

events.title: Observing a Tumultuous Political Rally
detailed_summary: Fogg, Aouda, and Fix reached Montgomery Street, finding it packed with people on sidewalks, streets, and even rooftops.
Individuals carried large posters, flags flew, and shouts for competing figures, Camerfield and Mandiboy, filled the air.
Fix identified the gathering as a political meeting and cautioned Fogg about potential danger within the crowd.
Fogg acknowledged the risk, wryly noting that political blows were still physical blows.
To get a better view without being caught in the throng, the group positioned themselves on a staircase overlooking the street.
Opposite them, a large outdoor platform was the focal point of the crowd's attention.
Fogg couldn't discern the specific purpose of the meeting, though he suspected it might be for nominating an official.
The crowd grew agitated, with hands raised (possibly voting) and people pushing; banners swayed and reappeared tattered.
The crowd's movement surged towards the steps where Fogg's party stood.
Fix speculated the meeting might concern the settled 'Alabama' issue or involve a confrontation between two rivals, whom he identified as Mr. Camerfield and Mr. Mandiboy.

events.text_segment:
They soon found themselves in Montgomery Street, where a great crowd was collected; the side-walks, street, horsecar rails, the shop-doors, the windows of the houses, and even the roofs, were full of people. Men were going about carrying large posters, and flags and streamers were floating in the wind; while loud cries were heard on every hand.
“Hurrah for Camerfield!”
“Hurrah for Mandiboy!”
It was a political meeting; at least so Fix conjectured, who said to Mr. Fogg, “Perhaps we had better not mingle with the crowd. There may be danger in it.”
“Yes,” returned Mr. Fogg; “and blows, even if they are political, are still blows.”
Fix smiled at this remark; and, in order to be able to see without being jostled about, the party took up a position on the top of a flight of steps situated at the upper end of Montgomery Street. Opposite them, on the other side of the street, between a coal wharf and a petroleum warehouse, a large platform had been erected in the open air, towards which the current of the crowd seemed to be directed.
For what purpose was this meeting? What was the occasion of this excited assemblage? Phileas Fogg could not imagine. Was it to nominate some high official—a governor or member of Congress? It was not improbable, so agitated was the multitude before them.
Just at this moment there was an unusual stir in the human mass. All the hands were raised in the air. Some, tightly closed, seemed to disappear suddenly in the midst of the cries—an energetic way, no doubt, of casting a vote. The crowd swayed back, the banners and flags wavered, disappeared an instant, then reappeared in tatters. The undulations of the human surge reached the steps, while all the heads floundered on the surface like a sea agitated by a squall. Many of the black hats disappeared, and the greater part of the crowd seemed to have diminished in height.
“It is evidently a meeting,” said Fix, “and its object must be an exciting one. I should not wonder if it were about the ‘Alabama,’ despite the fact that that question is settled.”
“Perhaps,” replied Mr. Fogg, simply.
“At least, there are two champions in presence of each other, the Honourable Mr. Camerfield and the Honourable Mr. Mandiboy.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
They soon found themselves in Montgomery Street, where a great crowd was collected; the sidewalks, street, horsecar rails, the shop-doors, the windows of the houses, and even the roofs, were full of people. The air buzzed with excitement as men, women, and children jostled for a better view, their faces alight with anticipation. Vendors weaved through the throng, hawking snacks and souvenirs, while newspaper boys shouted the latest headlines about the extraordinary wager that had captured the city’s imagination.  

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, adjusted his hat and surveyed the scene with mild curiosity. Passepartout, however, was wide-eyed, marveling at the sheer spectacle. "Mon Dieu!" he exclaimed. "It seems all of San Francisco has turned out to see us off!"  

Indeed, word of Fogg’s audacious journey had spread like wildfire, transforming their departure into a public event. The crowd erupted into cheers as the two men made their way toward the station, where their next mode of transport—a train bound for the East—awaited. Policemen struggled to maintain order, their whistles barely audible over the din.  

A reporter pushed forward, notebook in hand. "Mr. Fogg! Do you truly believe you can circumnavigate the globe in eighty days?"  

Fogg, unperturbed, replied in his usual measured tone, "The calculations are sound, sir. The world has grown smaller, and time waits for no man." His words only fueled the crowd’s fascination, and another wave of applause rose around them.  

As they boarded the train, Passepartout cast one last glance at the sea of faces. "I never imagined our journey would cause such a stir," he mused.  

Fogg settled into his seat, already consulting his timetable. "The journey is what matters, Passepartout, not the spectators."  

With a final whistle, the train lurched forward, leaving the cheering crowd behind. The next leg of their adventure had begun, and the eyes of the world seemed to follow them every step of the way.

events.title: Caught in the Political Brawl and Confrontation
detailed_summary: Aouda watched the chaotic scene with surprise, while Fix tried to ascertain the cause from a bystander.
Before getting an answer, the situation escalated further with renewed shouting and the use of banner staffs as weapons.
Fistfights broke out, projectiles like boots flew through the air, and Fogg thought he heard gunshots.
The crowd pushed towards the stairway, indicating one faction was being forced back, though it was unclear who.
Fix urged retreat, concerned for Fogg's safety and wary of anti-English sentiment if they were recognized.
As Fogg began to respond about being an English subject, a loud commotion erupted behind them.
A group supporting Mandiboy arrived, flanking the Camerfield supporters and trapping Fogg, Aouda, and Fix in the middle.
The rush of men armed with sticks was overwhelming; Fogg and Fix were jostled while trying to shield Aouda.
Fogg attempted to defend himself using his fists but was ineffective against the mob.
A large, red-bearded man, apparently the leader, raised his fist to strike Fogg.
Fix intervened, taking the blow meant for Fogg, resulting in a large bruise and a crushed hat.
Fogg contemptuously identified the attacker as a "Yankee".
The attacker retorted "Englishman!" and vowed they would meet again.
Fogg coolly agreed and exchanged names: Phileas Fogg and Colonel Stamp Proctor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda, leaning upon Mr. Fogg’s arm, observed the tumultuous scene with surprise, while Fix asked a man near him what the cause of it all was.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Colonel Stamp Proctor.”

events.text_segment:
Aouda, leaning upon Mr. Fogg’s arm, observed the tumultuous scene with surprise, while Fix asked a man near him what the cause of it all was. Before the man could reply, a fresh agitation arose; hurrahs and excited shouts were heard; the staffs of the banners began to be used as offensive weapons; and fists flew about in every direction. Thumps were exchanged from the tops of the carriages and omnibuses which had been blocked up in the crowd. Boots and shoes went whirling through the air, and Mr. Fogg thought he even heard the crack of revolvers mingling in the din, the rout approached the stairway, and flowed over the lower step. One of the parties had evidently been repulsed; but the mere lookers-on could not tell whether Mandiboy or Camerfield had gained the upper hand.
“It would be prudent for us to retire,” said Fix, who was anxious that Mr. Fogg should not receive any injury, at least until they got back to London. “If there is any question about England in all this, and we were recognised, I fear it would go hard with us.”
“An English subject—” began Mr. Fogg.
He did not finish his sentence; for a terrific hubbub now arose on the terrace behind the flight of steps where they stood, and there were frantic shouts of, “Hurrah for Mandiboy! Hip, hip, hurrah!”
It was a band of voters coming to the rescue of their allies, and taking the Camerfield forces in flank. Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Fix found themselves between two fires; it was too late to escape. The torrent of men, armed with loaded canes and sticks, was irresistible. Phileas Fogg and Fix were roughly hustled in their attempts to protect their fair companion; the former, as cool as ever, tried to defend himself with the weapons which nature has placed at the end of every Englishman’s arm, but in vain. A big brawny fellow with a red beard, flushed face, and broad shoulders, who seemed to be the chief of the band, raised his clenched fist to strike Mr. Fogg, whom he would have given a crushing blow, had not Fix rushed in and received it in his stead. An enormous bruise immediately made its appearance under the detective’s silk hat, which was completely smashed in.
“Yankee!” exclaimed Mr. Fogg, darting a contemptuous look at the ruffian.
“Englishman!” returned the other. “We will meet again!”
“When you please.”
“What is your name?”
“Phileas Fogg. And yours?”
“Colonel Stamp Proctor.”

Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

*Aouda, leaning upon Mr. Fogg’s arm, observed the tumultuous scene with surprise, while Fix asked a man near him what the cause of it all was. Before the man could reply, a terrific struggle arose. The yells of "Hurrah for Mandiboy!" and "Hurrah for Camerfield!" resounded on all sides. Sticks and fists were used freely, and boots flew through the air with the rapidity of grape-shot. The mob surged towards the stairway, and the foremost among them had already reached the upper steps, when the door was suddenly thrown open, revealing Mandiboy himself, who, with a well-directed blow, sent the intruders tumbling head over heels down the stairs. Mr. Fogg and his companions found themselves in the very midst of the opposing factions. It was too late to retreat. The torrent of men, armed with loaded canes and sticks, was irresistible. Phileas Fogg and Fix were roughly hustled in their attempts to protect Aouda, who was quite as composed as her companion. The latter would have used his fists—weapons which nature has bestowed upon every Englishman—had not a strapping fellow with a red beard, flushed face, and broad shoulders appeared at the head of the crowd, and raised his formidable fist over Mr. Fogg. Fix, however, stepped forward and received the blow in his stead, and an enormous bruise immediately made its appearance under his derby hat, which was completely smashed in. "Yankee!" exclaimed Mr. Fogg, darting a contemptuous look at the ruffian. "Englishman!" retorted the other. "We shall meet again!" "Whenever you please." "What is your name?" "Phileas Fogg. And yours?" "Colonel Stamp Proctor."*  

---

Aouda, leaning upon Mr. Fogg’s arm, observed the tumultuous scene with surprise, while Fix asked a man near him what the cause of it all was. The man, a burly fellow with a thick beard, turned to Fix with a look of excitement.  

“It’s the election, sir!” he exclaimed. “The city’s in an uproar over the candidates—riots in the streets, speeches at every corner. Tempers are running high!”  

Fix frowned. “An election? Here?”  

“Aye,” the man nodded vigorously. “And not just any election. The Reform Party and the Conservatives are at each other’s throats. Blood’s been spilled already, mark my words.”  

Aouda tightened her grip on Phileas Fogg’s arm, her dark eyes wide with concern. “Is it safe for us to remain here?” she murmured.  

Fogg, ever unflappable, adjusted his watch with his free hand. “We have precisely twenty-three minutes before our train departs. There is no cause for alarm.”  

Fix, however, was less assured. His eyes darted about the crowd, noting the clenched fists and heated arguments. He had spent weeks chasing Fogg across continents, and the last thing he needed was a political riot delaying their journey further.  

Just then, a group of shouting men surged toward them, waving banners and sticks. Fix instinctively stepped back, but Fogg stood firm, shielding Aouda with his usual calm.  

“Make way!” bellowed one of the rioters, shoving past.  

Aouda gasped as the crowd jostled them, but Fogg’s steady presence kept her from stumbling. Fix, now thoroughly alarmed, grabbed Fogg’s sleeve. “We must leave at once! This is no place for—”  

Before he could finish, a rock flew through the air, striking a nearby lamppost with a sharp crack. The crowd erupted into chaos, scattering in all directions.  

Fogg, without hesitation, guided Aouda toward the station, his pace brisk but unhurried. Fix hurried after them, muttering under his breath about reckless Englishmen and impossible schedules.  

As they reached the platform, the whistle of their train sounded. Fogg checked his watch once more. “Eighteen minutes remaining. We shall board without difficulty.”  

Aouda, still shaken, managed a small smile. “Your composure is remarkable, Mr. Fogg.”  

“Efficiency, my dear Aouda,” he replied, “is merely a matter of timing.”  

And with that, they stepped onto the train, leaving the riotous city behind—just as Phileas Fogg had planned.

events.title: Aftermath and Attire Repair
detailed_summary: The crowd moved past, knocking Fix down momentarily; he quickly recovered, though his clothes were torn.
Fix was bruised but not seriously injured; his coat was ripped, and his trousers damaged.
Aouda remained unharmed.
Fogg thanked Fix for his intervention.
Fix dismissed the thanks and suggested they find a tailor.
The visit was necessary as both Fogg's and Fix's clothing were in tatters.
They spent an hour getting suitably re-dressed before returning with Aouda to the hotel.

events.text_segment:
The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes. Happily, he was not seriously hurt. His travelling overcoat was divided into two unequal parts, and his trousers resembled those of certain Indians, which fit less compactly than they are easy to put on. Aouda had escaped unharmed, and Fix alone bore marks of the fray in his black and blue bruise.
“Thanks,” said Mr. Fogg to the detective, as soon as they were out of the crowd.
“No thanks are necessary,” replied Fix; “but let us go.”
“Where?”
“To a tailor’s.”
Such a visit was, indeed, opportune. The clothing of both Mr. Fogg and Fix was in rags, as if they had themselves been actively engaged in the contest between Camerfield and Mandiboy. An hour after, they were once more suitably attired, and with Aouda returned to the International Hotel.

events.title: Reconciliation, Departure Preparations, and Boarding the Train
detailed_summary: Passepartout awaited Fogg at the hotel, having acquired several revolvers.
He initially frowned upon seeing Fix with his master.
Aouda quickly explained the events of the political rally and Fix's actions.
Hearing this, Passepartout's demeanor changed, accepting Fix as an ally who was upholding his promise.
After dinner, a coach arrived to take them to the train station.
As they boarded, Fogg asked Fix if he had encountered Colonel Proctor again, which Fix denied.
Fogg calmly stated his intention to return to America specifically to find Proctor and retaliate for the insult.
Fix smiled silently, recognizing Fogg's adherence to a code of honor regarding such confrontations abroad.
At 5:45 p.m., they reached the station where the train was ready.
Before boarding, Fogg asked a porter about the day's disturbance in San Francisco.
The porter explained it was just a political meeting for an election.
Fogg inquired if it was for a high office like general-in-chief.
The porter clarified it was only for the election of a justice of the peace.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was waiting for his master, armed with half a dozen six-barrelled revolvers. When he perceived Fix, he knit his brows; but Aouda having, in a few words, told him of their adventure, his countenance resumed its placid expression. Fix evidently was no longer an enemy, but an ally; he was faithfully keeping his word.
Dinner over, the coach which was to convey the passengers and their luggage to the station drew up to the door. As he was getting in, Mr. Fogg said to Fix, “You have not seen this Colonel Proctor again?”
“No.”
“I will come back to America to find him,” said Phileas Fogg calmly. “It would not be right for an Englishman to permit himself to be treated in that way, without retaliating.”
The detective smiled, but did not reply. It was clear that Mr. Fogg was one of those Englishmen who, while they do not tolerate duelling at home, fight abroad when their honour is attacked.
At a quarter before six the travellers reached the station, and found the train ready to depart. As he was about to enter it, Mr. Fogg called a porter, and said to him: “My friend, was there not some trouble to-day in San Francisco?”
“It was a political meeting, sir,” replied the porter.
“But I thought there was a great deal of disturbance in the streets.”
“It was only a meeting assembled for an election.”
“The election of a general-in-chief, no doubt?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“No, sir; of a justice of the peace.”
Phileas Fogg got into the train, which started off at full speed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Passepartout stood on the deck of the steamship *Mongolia*, his hands gripping the cold metal of six-barrelled revolvers, his eyes scanning the bustling port of Bombay with nervous anticipation. Though he was a man of peace by nature, the urgency of their mission—to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days—had forced him to take drastic measures. The streets of India were unpredictable, and after their narrow escape from the Sioux in America, he was determined not to let any further mishaps delay Mr. Fogg’s journey.  

His master, Phileas Fogg, had remained as composed as ever, treating the entire affair with the same detached precision as a game of whist. But Passepartout knew better than to underestimate the dangers ahead. The revolvers, though excessive, were a precaution—one he hoped he would never have to use.  

As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting long shadows over the docks, Passepartout’s grip tightened. He had heard whispers of bandits along the railway to Calcutta, and the thought of an ambush sent a shiver down his spine. Yet, for all his anxiety, he trusted in Fogg’s unshakable resolve. If anyone could defy time itself, it was the unflappable Englishman.  

A whistle blew in the distance, signaling the imminent departure of their train. Passepartout exhaled slowly, tucking the revolvers into his coat. Whatever lay ahead, he was ready. For honor, for the wager, and most of all—for his master. The clock was ticking, and the world would not wait.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXVI. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AND PARTY TRAVEL BY THE PACIFIC RAILROAD

events.title: The Great American Railway Network
detailed_summary: The term "From ocean to ocean" signifies the primary railway line spanning the United States.
This Pacific Railroad system is composed of two main sections: the Central Pacific (San Francisco to Ogden) and the Union Pacific (Ogden to Omaha).
Omaha connects to New York via five principal railway lines.
An unbroken railway line of 3,786 miles connects New York and San Francisco.
The section between Omaha and the Pacific crosses territories inhabited by Indigenous peoples and wildlife, as well as lands settled by Mormons after their expulsion from Illinois in 1845.
The railway drastically reduced the coast-to-coast journey time from a minimum of six months to just seven days.
The decision to build the railway between the 41st and 42nd parallels was made in 1862, despite opposition from Southern representatives advocating a more southern route.
President Lincoln designated Omaha, Nebraska, as the line's terminus.
Construction commenced immediately with notable American speed and efficiency, achieving roughly 1.5 miles of track laid per day on the prairies.
Locomotives used the newly laid tracks to transport materials for the next day's construction.
The Pacific Railroad integrates with several branch lines across Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, and Oregon.

The route from Omaha follows the Platte River, crosses the Laramie territory and Wahsatch Mountains, skirts the Great Salt Lake reaching Salt Lake City, traverses the Tuilla Valley, American Desert, Cedar and Humboldt Mountains, and the Sierra Nevada, finally descending through Sacramento to the Pacific.
The railway's grade, even through the Rocky Mountains, does not exceed 112 feet per mile.
This seven-day railway journey was essential for Phileas Fogg's plan to reach New York by December 11th to board the steamer for Liverpool.

events.text_segment:
“From ocean to ocean”—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the “great trunk line” which crosses the entire width of the United States. The Pacific Railroad is, however, really divided into two distinct lines: the Central Pacific, between San Francisco and Ogden, and the Union Pacific, between Ogden and Omaha. Five main lines connect Omaha with New York.
New York and San Francisco are thus united by an uninterrupted metal ribbon, which measures no less than three thousand seven hundred and eighty-six miles. Between Omaha and the Pacific the railway crosses a territory which is still infested by Indians and wild beasts, and a large tract which the Mormons, after they were driven from Illinois in 1845, began to colonise.
The journey from New York to San Francisco consumed, formerly, under the most favourable conditions, at least six months. It is now accomplished in seven days.
It was in 1862 that, in spite of the Southern Members of Congress, who wished a more southerly route, it was decided to lay the road between the forty-first and forty-second parallels. President Lincoln himself fixed the end of the line at Omaha, in Nebraska. The work was at once commenced, and pursued with true American energy; nor did the rapidity with which it went on injuriously affect its good execution. The road grew, on the prairies, a mile and a half a day. A locomotive, running on the rails laid down the evening before, brought the rails to be laid on the morrow, and advanced upon them as fast as they were put in position.
The Pacific Railroad is joined by several branches in Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, and Oregon. On leaving Omaha, it passes along the left bank of the Platte River as far as the junction of its northern branch, follows its southern branch, crosses the Laramie territory and the Wahsatch Mountains, turns the Great Salt Lake, and reaches Salt Lake City, the Mormon capital, plunges into the Tuilla Valley, across the American Desert, Cedar and Humboldt Mountains, the Sierra Nevada, and descends, viâ Sacramento, to the Pacific—its grade, even on the Rocky Mountains, never exceeding one hundred and twelve feet to the mile.
Such was the road to be traversed in seven days, which would enable Phileas Fogg—at least, so he hoped—to take the Atlantic steamer at New York on the 11th for Liverpool.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the full text segment from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne, corresponding to the provided metadata:

---

**CHAPTER XXVI. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AND PARTY TRAVEL BY THE PACIFIC RAILROAD**  

“From ocean to ocean”—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the “great trunk line” which crosses the entire width of the United States. The Pacific Railroad is, however, really divided into two distinct lines: the Central Pacific, between San Francisco and Ogden, and the Union Pacific, between Ogden and Omaha. Five main lines connect Omaha with New York.  

New York and San Francisco are thus united by an uninterrupted metal ribbon, which measures no less than three thousand seven hundred and eighty-six miles. Between Omaha and the Pacific the railway crosses a territory which is still infested by Indians and wild beasts, and a large tract which the Mormons, after they were driven from Illinois in 1845, began to colonize.  

The journey from New York to San Francisco consumed, formerly, under the most favorable conditions, at least six months. It is now accomplished in seven days.  

It was in 1862 that, in spite of the Southern Members of Congress, who wished a more southerly route, it was decided to lay the road between the forty-first and forty-second parallels. President Lincoln himself fixed the end of the line at Omaha, in Nebraska. The work was at once commenced, and pursued with true American energy; nor did the rapidity with which it went on injuriously affect its good execution. The road grew, on the prairies, a mile and a half a day. A locomotive, running on the rails laid down the evening before, brought the rails to be laid on the morrow, and advanced upon them as fast as they were put in position.  

The Pacific Railroad is joined by several branches in Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, and Oregon. On leaving Omaha, it passes along the left bank of the Platte River as far as the junction of its northern branch, follows the southern branch, crosses the Laramie territory and the Wahsatch Mountains, turns the Great Salt Lake, and reaches Salt Lake City, the Mormon capital, plunges into the Tuilla Valley, across the American Desert, Cedar and Humboldt Mountains, the Sierra Nevada, and descends, via Sacramento, to the Pacific—its grade, even on the Rocky Mountains, never exceeding one hundred and twelve feet to the mile.  

Such was the road to be traversed in seven days, which would enable Phileas Fogg—at least, so he hoped—to take the Atlantic steamer at New York on the 11th for Liverpool.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
**"From ocean to ocean"—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the "great trunk line" which crosses the entire width of the United States. This monumental railway, stretching from the bustling ports of the Atlantic to the golden shores of the Pacific, was more than a feat of engineering—it was a symbol of progress, unity, and the relentless spirit of a nation hurtling toward modernity.  

For Phileas Fogg, the unflappable Englishman who had wagered his fortune on circumnavigating the globe in eighty days, this transcontinental railroad was a critical link in his audacious journey. As he boarded the train in New York, the vastness of America unfolded before him—endless prairies, towering mountains, and sprawling deserts, all now tamed by the iron tracks of human ambition. The journey was a marvel of efficiency, whisking passengers across a continent that had once taken pioneers months to traverse.  

Yet, the railroad was not without its perils. Bandits lurked in the untamed West, and the tracks themselves were sometimes precarious, laid hastily across rugged terrain. Fogg, ever composed, regarded these dangers with his usual indifference, trusting in the precision of his schedule. His companion, Passepartout, however, found the adventure far more thrilling—and occasionally alarming—as the train rattled through Sioux territory or skirted the edges of vertiginous cliffs.  

The "great trunk line" was more than a convenience; it was a microcosm of America itself—a land of contrasts, where the civilized East gave way to the wild frontier, where the hum of industry met the silence of the plains. For Fogg, it was merely another calculated step in his race against time, but for the world, it stood as proof that no distance was too great, no obstacle too formidable, for the determined will of mankind.  

As the train steamed toward San Francisco, where the next leg of Fogg’s journey awaited, the significance of the railroad was clear: it had shrunk the world, binding continents together and making the impossible merely routine. And for a man like Phileas Fogg, who had staked everything on the precision of timetables and the infallibility of progress, there could be no greater ally than the iron road that carried him ever forward—from ocean to ocean.

events.title: Aboard the Transcontinental Train
detailed_summary: The train car Phileas Fogg traveled in resembled a lengthy, open-plan bus mounted on eight wheels.
Inside, seats were arranged in two rows along the sides, separated by a central aisle leading to platforms at both ends.
These platforms were standard throughout the train, permitting passengers to move freely between cars.
The train boasted various amenities, including saloon cars, balcony cars, restaurants, and smoking cars; only theatre cars were absent, though anticipated in the future.
Vendors selling books, newspapers, food, beverages, and cigars constantly moved through the aisles, finding many buyers.
The train departed from Oakland station at 6:00 PM.
The evening was cold and gloomy, with overcast skies suggesting imminent snow.
The train proceeded at a moderate pace, averaging about twenty miles per hour including stops, deemed sufficient to arrive in Omaha on schedule.
Conversation among passengers was minimal, and many quickly drifted off to sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was but little conversation in the car, and soon many of the passengers were overcome with sleep.

events.text_segment:
The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior. It was supplied with two rows of seats, perpendicular to the direction of the train on either side of an aisle which conducted to the front and rear platforms. These platforms were found throughout the train, and the passengers were able to pass from one end of the train to the other. It was supplied with saloon cars, balcony cars, restaurants, and smoking-cars; theatre cars alone were wanting, and they will have these some day.
Book and news dealers, sellers of edibles, drinkables, and cigars, who seemed to have plenty of customers, were continually circulating in the aisles.
The train left Oakland station at six o’clock. It was already night, cold and cheerless, the heavens being overcast with clouds which seemed to threaten snow. The train did not proceed rapidly; counting the stoppages, it did not run more than twenty miles an hour, which was a sufficient speed, however, to enable it to reach Omaha within its designated time.
There was but little conversation in the car, and soon many of the passengers were overcome with sleep.

*The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior. It was supplied with two rows of seats, perpendicular to the direction of the train on either side of an aisle which conducted to the front and rear platforms. These platforms were found throughout the train, and the passengers were able to pass from one end of the train to the other. It was supplied with saloon cars, balcony cars, restaurants, and smoking-cars; theatre cars alone were wanting, and they will have these some day. Book and news dealers, sellers of edibles, drinkables, and cigars, who seemed to have plenty of customers, were continually circulating in the aisles. The train left Oakland station at six o'clock. It was already night, cold and cheerless, the heavens being overcast with clouds which seemed to threaten snow. The train did not proceed rapidly; including the stops, it did not run more than twenty miles an hour, which was a sufficient speed, however, to enable it to reach Omaha within its designated time. There was but little conversation in the car, and soon many of the passengers were sound asleep.*  

This passage is from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne, Chapter XXVI, describing Phileas Fogg's journey aboard the Pacific Railroad.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior. It was furnished with rows of plain wooden benches, where passengers sat facing one another in close quarters. The lack of partitions made the space feel open yet crowded, as travelers of all kinds—merchants, laborers, and adventurers—shared the same cramped area. The windows were small and let in only narrow shafts of light, casting flickering shadows as the train rattled along the uneven tracks.  

Despite its simplicity, the omnibus was sturdy, built to endure long journeys across vast landscapes. The rhythmic clatter of the wheels against the rails provided a constant, almost hypnotic background noise. Occasionally, the shrill whistle of the locomotive pierced the air, signaling another stop or warning of an approaching curve.  

Inside, the air was thick with the mingling scents of tobacco, sweat, and the faint metallic tang of the train itself. Yet, for all its discomforts, the omnibus carried its passengers steadily forward, a humble but reliable vessel in Phileas Fogg’s race against time.

events.title: Nightfall, Tension, and Transformation
detailed_summary: Passepartout was seated near Detective Fix, but avoided conversation due to the cooling of their relations after recent incidents.
Any previous mutual understanding or closeness between them had dissipated.
While Fix's outward behavior remained unchanged, Passepartout adopted a reserved stance, feeling hostile towards his former acquaintance.
About an hour into the journey, a fine snow began to fall, but it wasn't heavy enough to hinder the train's progress.
Visibility through the windows was limited to a vast expanse of white, against which the locomotive's smoke appeared greyish.
At 8:00 PM, a steward announced it was time to prepare for bed.
The car rapidly transformed into a sleeping compartment.
Seatbacks were adjusted, cleverly stored bedsteads were deployed, and berths were quickly set up.
Each traveler soon had access to a comfortable bed equipped with clean sheets, soft pillows, and thick curtains for privacy.
Passengers settled in for the night as the train continued its journey through California.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It only remained to go to bed and sleep which everybody did—while the train sped on across the State of California.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him. After recent events, their relations with each other had grown somewhat cold; there could no longer be mutual sympathy or intimacy between them. Fix’s manner had not changed; but Passepartout was very reserved, and ready to strangle his former friend on the slightest provocation.
Snow began to fall an hour after they started, a fine snow, however, which happily could not obstruct the train; nothing could be seen from the windows but a vast, white sheet, against which the smoke of the locomotive had a greyish aspect.
At eight o’clock a steward entered the car and announced that the time for going to bed had arrived; and in a few minutes the car was transformed into a dormitory. The backs of the seats were thrown back, bedsteads carefully packed were rolled out by an ingenious system, berths were suddenly improvised, and each traveller had soon at his disposition a comfortable bed, protected from curious eyes by thick curtains. The sheets were clean and the pillows soft. It only remained to go to bed and sleep which everybody did—while the train sped on across the State of California.

Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him. The air between them was thick with unspoken tension, for Passepartout had long suspected Fix of harboring ill intentions toward his master, Phileas Fogg. As the train rumbled onward, Passepartout gazed out the window at the passing landscape, lost in thought. Fix, meanwhile, pretended to read a newspaper, though his eyes occasionally flickered toward Passepartout. The stakes were too high—his career, even his honor, depended on arresting Fogg at the right moment.  

Silence stretched between them, heavy with secrets, as the train carried them ever closer to their next destination.

events.title: Through California and the Sierra Nevada
detailed_summary: The landscape between San Francisco and Sacramento featured gentle hills.
The Central Pacific line originates in Sacramento and extends eastward.
The route from San Francisco to Sacramento followed a north-easterly path along the American River.
This 120-mile stretch was covered in six hours.
Passengers passed through Sacramento, the state capital, around midnight while asleep, thus seeing none of its notable features like quays, streets, hotels, or public buildings.
Departing Sacramento, the train travelled through several junctions and towns (Roclin, Auburn, Colfax) before ascending into the Sierra Nevada mountain range.
The train reached Cisco at 7:00 AM.
An hour later, the sleeping car was converted back into a regular passenger car.
Travelers could then admire the striking mountain scenery.

The railway track navigated the mountain passes, sometimes running close to slopes, sometimes overhanging precipices, using bold curves to manage sharp angles and passing through narrow, seemingly dead-end defiles.
The locomotive, with its distinctive light, bell, and cow-catcher, produced loud sounds that echoed alongside the noises of mountain streams, its smoke drifting among large pine trees.
The route featured few bridges or tunnels, instead winding along the contours of the mountains rather than taking more direct, nature-altering paths.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The railway turned around the sides of the mountains, and did not attempt to violate nature by taking the shortest cut from one point to another.

events.text_segment:
The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly. The Central Pacific, taking Sacramento for its starting-point, extends eastward to meet the road from Omaha. The line from San Francisco to Sacramento runs in a north-easterly direction, along the American River, which empties into San Pablo Bay. The one hundred and twenty miles between these cities were accomplished in six hours, and towards midnight, while fast asleep, the travellers passed through Sacramento; so that they saw nothing of that important place, the seat of the State government, with its fine quays, its broad streets, its noble hotels, squares, and churches.
The train, on leaving Sacramento, and passing the junction, Roclin, Auburn, and Colfax, entered the range of the Sierra Nevada. ’Cisco was reached at seven in the morning; and an hour later the dormitory was transformed into an ordinary car, and the travellers could observe the picturesque beauties of the mountain region through which they were steaming. The railway track wound in and out among the passes, now approaching the mountain-sides, now suspended over precipices, avoiding abrupt angles by bold curves, plunging into narrow defiles, which seemed to have no outlet. The locomotive, its great funnel emitting a weird light, with its sharp bell, and its cow-catcher extended like a spur, mingled its shrieks and bellowings with the noise of torrents and cascades, and twined its smoke among the branches of the gigantic pines.
There were few or no bridges or tunnels on the route. The railway turned around the sides of the mountains, and did not attempt to violate nature by taking the shortest cut from one point to another.

The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly. The Central Valley stretches out in a vast, fertile plain, dotted with farms, orchards, and small towns. The landscape is dominated by golden fields of grain, vineyards heavy with grapes, and endless rows of fruit trees. The soil here is rich, nourished by the rivers that wind their way through the valley, making it one of the most productive agricultural regions in the world.  

As the train from San Francisco speeds toward Sacramento, passengers can see cattle grazing lazily in the pastures and workers tending to the crops under the warm California sun. The air is thick with the scent of earth and growing things, a stark contrast to the salty breeze of the coast. Small stations along the way mark the progress of the journey, each one a brief pause in the otherwise steady advance toward the state capital.  

The flatness of the land allows the train to maintain a swift pace, unimpeded by the steep grades and sharp curves that slow travel in more mountainous regions. The rhythmic clatter of the wheels against the tracks is a constant companion, blending with the occasional whistle that signals the approach to another crossing or town.  

In the distance, the Sierra Nevada mountains rise like a blue haze on the horizon, a reminder that beyond this tranquil valley lie the rugged peaks and deep forests that have shaped so much of California’s history. But here, in the heart of the Central Valley, the land is open, gentle, and endlessly fruitful—a testament to nature’s bounty and man’s labor.

events.title: Buffalo Herd Causes Major Delay
detailed_summary: Around 9:00 AM, the train crossed into Nevada via the Carson Valley, continuing its northeast trajectory.
At noon, it arrived in Reno, pausing for a twenty-minute breakfast stop.
From Reno, the railway followed the Humboldt River north for some distance before turning eastward, staying near the river until reaching the Humboldt Range at Nevada's eastern edge.
After breakfast, Mr. Fogg and his companions returned to their seats, observing the changing scenery of prairies, distant mountains, and streams.
Occasionally, immense herds of buffalo appeared in the distance like moving barriers.
These vast herds frequently posed significant obstacles to trains, sometimes halting them for hours as thousands of animals crossed the tracks in dense formations.
Around midday, the train encountered such an obstacle: a massive herd of ten to twelve thousand buffalo blocking the way.
The locomotive reduced speed and attempted to nudge the animals aside with its cow-catcher, but the sheer number of buffalo made this impossible.
The animals proceeded calmly, occasionally letting out loud bellows, their movement seemingly unstoppable like a 'torrent of living flesh'.
Passengers observed this unusual sight from the train's platforms.
Phileas Fogg, despite having the most pressing schedule, remained seated, calmly and philosophically awaiting the herd's passage.
Passepartout grew increasingly agitated by the delay, expressing a desire to use his revolvers on the animals.
He exclaimed about the absurdity of mere cattle halting trains and wondered aloud if Fogg had factored such an event into his plans.
He also criticized the train's engineer for not attempting to force a passage through the herd.

The engineer, however, acted prudently by not confronting the buffalo, understanding that while the initial impact might clear some animals, the locomotive would quickly be overwhelmed, leading to derailment and immobilization.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.
From this point the road, running along Humboldt River, passed northward for several miles by its banks; then it turned eastward, and kept by the river until it reached the Humboldt Range, nearly at the extreme eastern limit of Nevada.
Having breakfasted, Mr. Fogg and his companions resumed their places in the car, and observed the varied landscape which unfolded itself as they passed along the vast prairies, the mountains lining the horizon, and the creeks, with their frothy, foaming streams. Sometimes a great herd of buffaloes, massing together in the distance, seemed like a moveable dam. These innumerable multitudes of ruminating beasts often form an insurmountable obstacle to the passage of the trains; thousands of them have been seen passing over the track for hours together, in compact ranks. The locomotive is then forced to stop and wait till the road is once more clear.
This happened, indeed, to the train in which Mr. Fogg was travelling. About twelve o’clock a troop of ten or twelve thousand head of buffalo encumbered the track. The locomotive, slackening its speed, tried to clear the way with its cow-catcher; but the mass of animals was too great. The buffaloes marched along with a tranquil gait, uttering now and then deafening bellowings. There was no use of interrupting them, for, having taken a particular direction, nothing can moderate and change their course; it is a torrent of living flesh which no dam could contain.
The travellers gazed on this curious spectacle from the platforms; but Phileas Fogg, who had the most reason of all to be in a hurry, remained in his seat, and waited philosophically until it should please the buffaloes to get out of the way.
Passepartout was furious at the delay they occasioned, and longed to discharge his arsenal of revolvers upon them.
“What a country!” cried he. “Mere cattle stop the trains, and go by in a procession, just as if they were not impeding travel! Parbleu! I should like to know if Mr. Fogg foresaw this mishap in his programme! And here’s an engineer who doesn’t dare to run the locomotive into this herd of beasts!”
The engineer did not try to overcome the obstacle, and he was wise. He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  

The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.  

From this point the railroad followed the Humboldt River in a northeasterly direction for some distance; then it turned eastward, and kept by the river until it reached the Humboldt Range, at the eastern limit of Nevada.  

Having breakfasted, Mr. Fogg and his companions resumed their places in the car, and observed the varied landscape which unfolded itself as they passed along—the vast prairies, the mountains lining the horizon, and the creeks, with their frothy, foaming streams. Sometimes a great herd of buffaloes, massing together in the distance, seemed like a movable dam. These innumerable multitudes of ruminating beasts often form an insurmountable obstacle to the passage of the trains; thousands of them have been seen passing over the track for hours together, in compact ranks.  

The locomotive was obliged to stop before this living barrier, and wait till the road was once more clear.  

This happened in the present case. About twelve o’clock, a troop of ten or twelve thousand head of buffalo encumbered the track. The locomotive, slackening its speed, tried to clear the way with its cow-catcher; but the mass of animals was too great. The buffaloes marched along with a tranquil gait, uttering now and then deafening bellowings. There was no use of interrupting them, for, having taken a particular direction, nothing can moderate and change their course; it is a torrent of living flesh which no dam could contain.  

The travellers gazed on this curious spectacle from the platforms; but Phileas Fogg, who had the most reason of all to be in a hurry, remained in his seat, and waited philosophically until it should please the buffaloes to get out of the way.  

Passepartout was furious at the delay they occasioned, and longed to discharge his arsenal of revolvers upon them.  

“What a country!” cried he. “Mere cattle stop the trains, and go by in a procession, just as if they were not impeding travel! Parbleu! I should like to know if Mr. Fogg foresaw this mishap in his programme! And here’s an engineer who doesn’t dare to run the locomotive into this herd of beasts!”  

The engineer did not try to overcome the obstacle, and he was wise. He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.  

---

This passage matches the given metadata, including the chapter title, characters involved, and the detailed summary of events. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

Passepartout, ever eager to explore, took the opportunity to observe the bustling station. The air was crisp, carrying the scent of pine from the distant mountains, and the sun shone brightly over the rugged landscape.  

Reno, though still a modest town in those days, was lively with miners, traders, and travelers making their way to the silver-rich regions of Nevada. Passepartout, always curious, struck up a conversation with a local vendor selling freshly baked bread and steaming coffee. The man, with a thick beard and a wide-brimmed hat, spoke of the gold and silver mines that had drawn fortune-seekers from across the country.  

Meanwhile, Fix, the detective who had been trailing Fogg since Suez, lurked nearby, watching his quarry closely. He had hoped to receive the long-awaited arrest warrant in San Francisco, but to his frustration, it had not yet arrived. Now, as the train prepared to continue its journey, Fix grew increasingly anxious. Time was slipping away, and if Fogg left American soil, his chances of apprehending him would diminish.  

Back on the train, Fogg remained oblivious to the detective’s presence, engrossed in his newspaper. Passepartout, however, noticed Fix’s lingering gaze and felt a flicker of suspicion. Still, he dismissed it as mere coincidence, unaware of the man’s true intentions.  

As the whistle blew, signaling the departure, the passengers hurried back aboard. The locomotive heaved forward, its wheels grinding against the tracks as it picked up speed. The vast Nevada desert stretched endlessly before them, dotted with sagebrush and rocky outcrops. The journey across America was far from over, and with each passing mile, Fogg’s relentless schedule pressed onward.  

Passepartout, gazing out the window, marveled at the stark beauty of the landscape. He wondered what other adventures lay ahead—unaware that danger, in the form of Fix’s relentless pursuit, was drawing ever closer. Yet for now, the rhythmic clatter of the train and the steady progress eastward filled him with quiet satisfaction.  

Fogg, ever composed, turned a page of his newspaper. The race against time continued, and not even the vast expanse of America could slow his determined stride.

events.title: Resuming the Journey into Utah
detailed_summary: The most sensible approach was to wait for the obstruction to clear and then make up the lost time by increasing the train's speed.
The buffalo procession continued for three full hours.
The railway track was finally clear as night began to fall.
The last of the buffalo herd crossed the rails just as the front ranks disappeared over the southern horizon.
At 8:00 PM, the train navigated through the narrow passages of the Humboldt Range.
By 9:30 PM, it had entered the territory of Utah, noted as the area of the Great Salt Lake and the distinctive Mormon settlement.
