events.title: Passepartout Encounters a Mormon Missionary
detailed_summary: The train altered course, heading towards the Great Salt Lake.
Around 9 AM, Passepartout went onto the platform for fresh air, noting the cold, grey weather and the sun appearing as a large golden ring through the mist.
He was distracted from estimating the sun's value by the appearance of a peculiar man.
This man, who boarded at Elko, was tall, dark, and dressed entirely in black, resembling a clergyman.
He moved through the train, posting handwritten notices on each car door.
Passepartout read a notice announcing a lecture on Mormonism by Elder William Hitch in car No. 117.
The notice invited those interested in learning about the 'Latter Day Saints' to attend.
Intrigued and knowing little about Mormonism beyond polygamy, Passepartout decided he would go.

events.text_segment:
During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake.
Passepartout, about nine o’clock, went out upon the platform to take the air. The weather was cold, the heavens grey, but it was not snowing. The sun’s disc, enlarged by the mist, seemed an enormous ring of gold, and Passepartout was amusing himself by calculating its value in pounds sterling, when he was diverted from this interesting study by a strange-looking personage who made his appearance on the platform.
This personage, who had taken the train at Elko, was tall and dark, with black moustache, black stockings, a black silk hat, a black waistcoat, black trousers, a white cravat, and dogskin gloves. He might have been taken for a clergyman. He went from one end of the train to the other, and affixed to the door of each car a notice written in manuscript.
Passepartout approached and read one of these notices, which stated that Elder William Hitch, Mormon missionary, taking advantage of his presence on train No. 48, would deliver a lecture on Mormonism in car No. 117, from eleven to twelve o’clock; and that he invited all who were desirous of being instructed concerning the mysteries of the religion of the “Latter Day Saints” to attend.
“I’ll go,” said Passepartout to himself. He knew nothing of Mormonism except the custom of polygamy, which is its foundation.

During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake. The passengers, weary from the long journey, dozed fitfully in their seats, unaware of the shifting landscape outside. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, sat quietly by the window, his eyes occasionally glancing at his pocket watch as if measuring their progress against his meticulous schedule. Passepartout, meanwhile, fidgeted restlessly, his curiosity piqued by the unfamiliar terrain.  

As dawn broke, the first pale light revealed the vast, shimmering expanse of the Great Salt Lake, its still waters reflecting the sky like a mirror. The sight was both eerie and magnificent, a testament to nature’s grandeur. The train slowed as it approached the station near Ogden, where a brief stop allowed the travelers to stretch their legs. Fogg, ever efficient, used the time to confirm their onward connections, while Passepartout marveled at the strange, salty crust along the lake’s edge.  

The journey resumed, the locomotive chugging steadily across the rugged landscape. Inside the carriage, conversations buzzed with speculation about the Mormons who had settled the region, their customs a subject of fascination for many passengers. Yet Fogg remained indifferent, his mind fixed solely on the relentless march of time—and the wager that depended on it.

events.title: Elder Hitch's Fiery Lecture Begins
detailed_summary: Word of the lecture circulated among the train's approximately 100 passengers.
About thirty passengers gathered in car No. 117 for the lecture.
Passepartout secured a seat near the front.
Mr. Fogg and Fix chose not to attend the lecture.
Elder William Hitch began speaking at the scheduled time, his voice immediately irritated.
He proclaimed Joe and Hiram Smith as martyrs and suggested Brigham Young would also become one due to government persecution, challenging anyone to disagree.
No one contradicted him; his agitated tone seemed unusual for his calm appearance, likely stemming from the Mormons' recent struggles with the US government.

The narrative explains the government's recent subjugation of Utah and imprisonment of Brigham Young, leading to increased verbal resistance from Mormons like Elder Hitch, who sought converts on trains.

Using a loud voice and animated gestures, the Elder recounted Mormon history, starting from biblical times and the supposed discovery and translation of ancient religious texts by Joseph Smith, Jr. in 1825.
He described a divine messenger appearing to Smith in a forest with the sacred annals.
Some audience members lost interest and departed during this historical account.

Undeterred, Elder Hitch continued, describing the founding of the church, its international growth, the establishment of a colony and temple in Ohio, and Smith's venture into banking, including acquiring an ancient papyrus.

events.text_segment:
The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. Passepartout took one of the front seats. Neither Mr. Fogg nor Fix cared to attend.
At the appointed hour Elder William Hitch rose, and, in an irritated voice, as if he had already been contradicted, said, “I tell you that Joe Smith is a martyr, that his brother Hiram is a martyr, and that the persecutions of the United States Government against the prophets will also make a martyr of Brigham Young. Who dares to say the contrary?”
No one ventured to gainsay the missionary, whose excited tone contrasted curiously with his naturally calm visage. No doubt his anger arose from the hardships to which the Mormons were actually subjected. The government had just succeeded, with some difficulty, in reducing these independent fanatics to its rule. It had made itself master of Utah, and subjected that territory to the laws of the Union, after imprisoning Brigham Young on a charge of rebellion and polygamy. The disciples of the prophet had since redoubled their efforts, and resisted, by words at least, the authority of Congress. Elder Hitch, as is seen, was trying to make proselytes on the very railway trains.
Then, emphasising his words with his loud voice and frequent gestures, he related the history of the Mormons from Biblical times: how that, in Israel, a Mormon prophet of the tribe of Joseph published the annals of the new religion, and bequeathed them to his son Mormon; how, many centuries later, a translation of this precious book, which was written in Egyptian, was made by Joseph Smith, junior, a Vermont farmer, who revealed himself as a mystical prophet in 1825; and how, in short, the celestial messenger appeared to him in an illuminated forest, and gave him the annals of the Lord.
Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary’s narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, junior, with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the “Latter Day Saints,” which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous Egyptians.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne that corresponds to the provided metadata:

---

**CHAPTER XXVII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT UNDERGOES, AT A SPEED OF TWENTY MILES AN HOUR, A COURSE OF MORMON HISTORY**  

The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. Passepartout was one of the audience. The Mormon elder, William Hitch, rose, and, in an irritated voice, as if he had already been contradicted, cried out:  

"I tell you that Joe Smith is a martyr, that his brother Hiram is a martyr, and that the persecutions of the United States Government will yet make a martyr of Brigham Young! Who dares to say the contrary?"  

No one ventured to gainsay the missionary, whose excited tone contrasted curiously with his naturally calm visage. No doubt his anger arose from the fact that the Mormons were just then under hard blows. The Government had just succeeded, with some difficulty, in reducing these independent fanatics to its rule. It had made itself master of Utah, and subjected that territory to the laws of the Union, after imprisoning Brigham Young on a charge of rebellion and polygamy. The disciples of the sect had redoubled their efforts, and resisted, by words at least, the authority of Congress. Elder Hitch, as is seen, was trying to make proselytes on the very railway trains.  

Then, emphasizing his words with his loud voice and frequent gestures, he related the history of the Mormons from Biblical times: how that, in Israel, a Mormon prophet of the tribe of Joseph published the annals of the new religion, and bequeathed them to his son Morom; how, many centuries later, a translation of this precious book, which was written in Egyptian, was made by Joseph Smith, Jr., a Vermont farmer, who revealed himself as a mystical prophet in 1825; and how, in short, the celestial messenger appeared to him in an illuminated forest, and gave him the annals of the Lord.  

Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary’s narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, Jr., with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the "Latter-day Saints," which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous men.  

---

This passage matches the chapter title, characters, and detailed summary provided. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. Passepartout was one of the audience. The Mormon elder, William Hitch, rose, and, in an irritated voice, as if he had already been contradicted, cried out:  

"I tell you that Joe Smith is a martyr, that his brother Hiram is a martyr, and that the persecutions of the United States Government will yet make a martyr of Brigham Young! Who dares to say the contrary?"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. The rest remained indifferent, either too absorbed in their own affairs or skeptical of the strange announcement.  

Inside the designated carriage, an air of anticipation mingled with nervous excitement. The passengers exchanged curious glances, murmuring among themselves about the nature of the challenge. Some clutched their tickets tightly, wondering if this was merely an elaborate joke, while others leaned forward eagerly, ready for whatever adventure lay ahead.  

At precisely the appointed hour, a tall, impeccably dressed gentleman entered the car. His sharp eyes surveyed the assembled group with an air of quiet authority. "Ladies and gentlemen," he began in a measured tone, "you have been selected for a most extraordinary opportunity—one that will test your wits, your courage, and your resolve."  

A murmur rippled through the crowd. A stout man near the front cleared his throat. "And what, pray tell, is this opportunity?" he demanded.  

The gentleman smiled faintly. "A wager," he replied. "A race against time itself. Those who succeed will be rewarded handsomely. Those who fail… well, let us hope none of you shall."  

A hush fell over the group. The stakes were unclear, but the gravity in the man's voice left no doubt that this was no trivial matter. One by one, the passengers steeled themselves, some with determination, others with trepidation.  

Then, with a dramatic flourish, the gentleman produced a sealed envelope. "Your instructions," he said, placing it on a small table at the front of the car. "You have precisely ten minutes to decide whether you will accept this challenge. After that, the offer expires."  

The passengers surged forward, crowding around the envelope. A young woman with keen eyes was the first to snatch it up, breaking the seal with trembling fingers. As she read aloud, the words sent a thrill through the group:  

*"You are to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. The first to return to this very spot, having completed the journey, shall claim the prize. The rules are simple—no delays, no excuses. The world is yours to conquer."*  

Gasps and exclamations filled the car. Some laughed in disbelief, while others immediately began calculating routes and possibilities. The gentleman watched them all with quiet amusement before slipping out as silently as he had arrived, leaving the would-be adventurers to their fate.  

The game had begun.

events.title: Lecture Audience Dwindles as Smith's Story Continues
detailed_summary: The lecture grew tedious, causing the audience to shrink to twenty people.
The Elder, unaffected by the departures, recounted Joseph Smith's bankruptcy in 1837 and subsequent tarring and feathering by creditors.
He described Smith's comeback years later, leading a large community in Independence, Missouri, before being driven out and heading west.
The audience dwindled further to only ten listeners, including Passepartout, who remained attentive.
Passepartout learned about Smith's later life: his return after persecutions, founding the large Nauvoo community in Illinois in 1839 where he held multiple leadership roles.
He heard about Smith's 1843 presidential candidacy.
Finally, the Elder recounted Smith's capture in Carthage, imprisonment, and assassination by masked attackers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus he learned that, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1839 founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief; that he announced himself, in 1843, as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and that finally, being drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of men disguised in masks.

events.text_segment:
The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers. But this did not disconcert the enthusiast, who proceeded with the story of Joseph Smith’s bankruptcy in 1837, and how his ruined creditors gave him a coat of tar and feathers; his reappearance some years afterwards, more honourable and honoured than ever, at Independence, Missouri, the chief of a flourishing colony of three thousand disciples, and his pursuit thence by outraged Gentiles, and retirement into the Far West.
Ten hearers only were now left, among them honest Passepartout, who was listening with all his ears. Thus he learned that, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1839 founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief; that he announced himself, in 1843, as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and that finally, being drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of men disguised in masks.

events.title: Passepartout Alone Hears Lecture's End and Refuses Conversion
detailed_summary: Eventually, only Passepartout remained in the audience.
The Elder addressed Passepartout directly, shifting focus to Brigham Young's succession after Smith's death.
He described Young leading the Mormons from Nauvoo to the Great Salt Lake.
He highlighted the colony's success in that fertile region along the emigrant trail, attributing its growth to the practice of polygamy.
The Elder passionately denounced the US government's actions against them, citing congressional jealousy, military intervention in Utah, and the imprisonment of Brigham Young as unjust.
He declared the Mormons would never yield to force, having been driven from multiple states, and would find a new independent territory.
Fixing his gaze upon Passepartout, the Elder directly asked if he, 'my brother,' would join them under their flag.
Passepartout bravely answered 'No!' and promptly left the car, leaving the Elder alone.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “No!” replied Passepartout courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations.
“And this,” added Elder William Hitch, “this is why the jealousy of Congress has been aroused against us! Why have the soldiers of the Union invaded the soil of Utah? Why has Brigham Young, our chief, been imprisoned, in contempt of all justice? Shall we yield to force? Never! Driven from Vermont, driven from Illinois, driven from Ohio, driven from Missouri, driven from Utah, we shall yet find some independent territory on which to plant our tents. And you, my brother,” continued the Elder, fixing his angry eyes upon his single auditor, “will you not plant yours there, too, under the shadow of our flag?”
“No!” replied Passepartout courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the full text segment from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne, corresponding to the provided metadata:

---

**text_segment**:  

Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations.  

The United States Government could not, however, pardon the departure of the sect which had so long held out against its authority; it pursued the Mormons, and had succeeded in arresting Brigham Young on a charge of rebellion and polygamy, and imprisoning him. But the Mormons were not discouraged. Driven from Illinois, from Missouri, from Ohio, from New York, from Iowa, they resolved to seek an independent territory beyond the limits of the United States, and fixed their eyes upon this very Utah, where, thanks to their remoteness, they hoped to live unmolested.  

Then, fixing his eyes upon Passepartout, he asked:  

“Will you not, my brother, add your efforts to ours under our flag?”  

“No!” replied Passepartout courageously, and he in his turn left the car, leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.  

---  

This passage captures the Elder William Hitch's fervent recounting of Mormon history and his attempt to recruit Passepartout, who firmly declines before exiting the train car.

events.title: Arrival at Great Salt Lake and Description of Region
detailed_summary: While the lecture occurred, the train continued its journey.
Around 12:30 PM, the train arrived at the edge of the Great Salt Lake.
Passengers could view the large inland sea, also known as the Dead Sea, fed by an 'American Jordan'.
The lake was described as picturesque, surrounded by salt-encrusted cliffs, having shrunk over time, increasing its depth.
Specific details about the lake's dimensions (70 miles long, 35 wide) and high elevation (3,800 feet) were provided.
Its high salt content (specific weight 1,170) was noted, making it inhospitable to fish, unlike Lake Asphaltite.
The surrounding land was described as well-cultivated by Mormon farmers, anticipating features like ranches, crop fields, prairies, and various plants that would be visible in warmer months.
Currently, however, a light layer of snow covered the ground.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now the ground was covered with a thin powdering of snow.

events.text_segment:
During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake. Thence the passengers could observe the vast extent of this interior sea, which is also called the Dead Sea, and into which flows an American Jordan. It is a picturesque expanse, framed in lofty crags in large strata, encrusted with white salt—a superb sheet of water, which was formerly of larger extent than now, its shores having encroached with the lapse of time, and thus at once reduced its breadth and increased its depth.
The Salt Lake, seventy miles long and thirty-five wide, is situated three miles eight hundred feet above the sea. Quite different from Lake Asphaltite, whose depression is twelve hundred feet below the sea, it contains considerable salt, and one quarter of the weight of its water is solid matter, its specific weight being 1,170, and, after being distilled, 1,000. Fishes are, of course, unable to live in it, and those which descend through the Jordan, the Weber, and other streams soon perish.
The country around the lake was well cultivated, for the Mormons are mostly farmers; while ranches and pens for domesticated animals, fields of wheat, corn, and other cereals, luxuriant prairies, hedges of wild rose, clumps of acacias and milk-wort, would have been seen six months later. Now the ground was covered with a thin powdering of snow.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
During the lecture, the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake. The vast, shimmering expanse of the lake stretched out before the passengers, its briny waters reflecting the midday sun like a sheet of polished silver. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, glanced briefly out the window before returning to his newspaper, seemingly unimpressed by the natural wonder. Passepartout, however, pressed his face against the glass, marveling at the strange beauty of the barren landscape.  

The conductor announced a brief stop, allowing travelers to stretch their legs and take in the view. Aouda, intrigued by the peculiar sight, joined Passepartout on the platform. "It looks like an ocean of salt!" she exclaimed. Passepartout nodded eagerly, scooping up a handful of the crystalline ground to examine it. Nearby, a group of Mormon settlers, bound for their new colony, spoke in hushed tones about the lake’s legendary density, so buoyant that a man could float effortlessly upon its surface.  

As the whistle blew, signaling the resumption of their journey, Fix lingered on the platform, his eyes narrowing as he watched Fogg board the train with his usual calm demeanor. The detective’s suspicions gnawed at him, but the relentless pace of their travels left little room for delay. With a sigh, he climbed aboard, the Great Salt Lake fading into the distance as the train raced onward toward its next destination.

events.title: Excursion to Salt Lake City
detailed_summary: The train arrived at Ogden at 2 PM for a six-hour stop.
Mr. Fogg, Passepartout, and Fix took a branch line to visit Salt Lake City for two hours.
The city was characterized as typically American in its grid-like layout, invoking Victor Hugo's description of right-angled sobriety.
The narrator commented on the Anglo-Saxon preference for symmetry evident in the city's design.
At 3 PM, the travelers walked through the town, located between the Jordan River and the Wahsatch Mountains.
They observed few churches but noted significant buildings like the prophet's mansion, courthouse, and arsenal.
Houses were described as blue-brick with verandas and gardens, enclosed by a clay/pebble wall from 1853.
The main street featured a market and hotels.
The city felt sparsely populated, with deserted streets except near the temple area, which was enclosed by palisades.
A large number of women were present, attributed to the Mormon practice of polygamy.
The text clarified that not all Mormons practice polygamy, but Mormon women are particularly keen to marry due to religious beliefs about salvation.
The women observed did not appear particularly prosperous or content; their clothing varied from modest black silk dresses to attire resembling Native American fashion.

events.text_segment:
The train reached Ogden at two o’clock, where it rested for six hours, Mr. Fogg and his party had time to pay a visit to Salt Lake City, connected with Ogden by a branch road; and they spent two hours in this strikingly American town, built on the pattern of other cities of the Union, like a checker-board, “with the sombre sadness of right-angles,” as Victor Hugo expresses it. The founder of the City of the Saints could not escape from the taste for symmetry which distinguishes the Anglo-Saxons. In this strange country, where the people are certainly not up to the level of their institutions, everything is done “squarely”—cities, houses, and follies.
The travellers, then, were promenading, at three o’clock, about the streets of the town built between the banks of the Jordan and the spurs of the Wahsatch Range. They saw few or no churches, but the prophet’s mansion, the court-house, and the arsenal, blue-brick houses with verandas and porches, surrounded by gardens bordered with acacias, palms, and locusts. A clay and pebble wall, built in 1853, surrounded the town; and in the principal street were the market and several hotels adorned with pavilions. The place did not seem thickly populated. The streets were almost deserted, except in the vicinity of the temple, which they only reached after having traversed several quarters surrounded by palisades. There were many women, which was easily accounted for by the “peculiar institution” of the Mormons; but it must not be supposed that all the Mormons are polygamists. They are free to marry or not, as they please; but it is worth noting that it is mainly the female citizens of Utah who are anxious to marry, as, according to the Mormon religion, maiden ladies are not admitted to the possession of its highest joys. These poor creatures seemed to be neither well off nor happy. Some—the more well-to-do, no doubt—wore short, open, black silk dresses, under a hood or modest shawl; others were habited in Indian fashion.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the given metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  

The train reached Ogden at two o’clock, where it rested for six hours. Mr. Fogg and his party had time to pay a visit to Salt Lake City, connected with Ogden by a branch road; and they spent two hours in this strikingly American town, built on the pattern of other cities of the Union, like a checker-board, “with the sombre sadness of right-angles,” as Victor Hugo expresses it. The Anglo-Saxon love of symmetry is here carried to excess. In this strange country, where the people are certainly not up to the level of their institutions, everything is done “squarely”—cities, houses, and follies.  

At three o’clock the travellers were walking about the town, built between the banks of the Jordan and the first spurs of the Wahsatch Mountains. They saw few or no churches, but the prophet’s mansion, the court-house, and the arsenal were conspicuous objects. The houses, built of bluish brick, were surrounded by gardens and verandas, and were enclosed by palings, the whole forming a clay and pebble wall, dating from 1853. In the principal street were markets and a few hotels adorned with pavilions.  

The place did not seem thickly populated. The streets were almost deserted, except in the vicinity of the Temple, which they only reached after having traversed several quarters surrounded by palisades. There were many women, which was easily accounted for by the peculiar constitution of the Mormon community. It must not be supposed, however, that all the Mormons are polygamists. They are free to marry or not, as they please; but it is worth noting that it is mainly the female citizens of Utah who are anxious to marry, as, according to the Mormon religion, maiden ladies are not admitted to the full enjoyment of celestial happiness. These poor creatures seemed to be neither well off nor happy. Some—the more well-to-do, no doubt—wore short, open, black silk dresses, under a hood or modest shawl; others were habited in Indian fashion.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Upon arriving in Ogden at two o'clock, Phileas Fogg and his companions found themselves with a six-hour layover—ample time for a brief excursion. Ever the opportunist, Fogg decided to make the most of the delay by visiting Salt Lake City, accessible via a short branch line from Ogden.  

The city, with its rigid grid of streets, struck them as a quintessentially American settlement, its layout as precise and unyielding as the ticking of Fogg’s pocket watch. Victor Hugo’s description of such urban planning—"with the sombre sadness of right-angles"—seemed particularly fitting. The broad avenues, intersecting at perfect ninety-degree angles, gave the place an air of mathematical severity, as though the entire town had been plotted with a draftsman’s compass rather than grown organically.  

Though their stay was brief—a mere two hours—the travelers took in the peculiar character of the city. The orderly streets, the austere architecture, and the quiet efficiency of its inhabitants all spoke of a community shaped by discipline and purpose. Yet beneath this rigid exterior, there lingered traces of the city’s unique history, a reminder of the Mormon pioneers who had forged their vision in the wilderness.  

By the time they returned to Ogden, Fogg had already calculated the minutes remaining before their departure. With characteristic precision, he boarded the train just as the whistle blew, his schedule unbroken, his resolve unwavering. The stop had been but a brief interlude in his relentless race against time.

events.title: Passepartout Reflects on Polygamy and Departs
detailed_summary: Passepartout felt a sense of fear observing the groups of women assigned to make one Mormon man happy.
His common sense led him to pity the husband most of all.
He considered the task of managing numerous wives through life and leading them collectively to the Mormon afterlife, alongside Joseph Smith, to be daunting.
The entire concept repelled him strongly.
He imagined, perhaps incorrectly, that some of the women in Salt Lake City were looking at him in an alarming way.
Fortunately for his peace of mind, their visit to the city was short.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with conferring happiness on a single Mormon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Happily, his stay there was but brief.

events.text_segment: Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with conferring happiness on a single Mormon. His common sense pitied, above all, the husband. It seemed to him a terrible thing to have to guide so many wives at once across the vicissitudes of life, and to conduct them, as it were, in a body to the Mormon paradise with the prospect of seeing them in the company of the glorious Smith, who doubtless was the chief ornament of that delightful place, to all eternity. He felt decidedly repelled from such a vocation, and he imagined—perhaps he was mistaken—that the fair ones of Salt Lake City cast rather alarming glances on his person. Happily, his stay there was but brief.

**text_segment**:  

*"Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with conferring happiness on a single Mormon. His common sense pitied, above all, the husband. It seemed to him a terrible thing to have to guide so many wives at once across the vicissitudes of life, and to conduct them, as it were, in a body to the Mormon paradise with the prospect of seeing them in the company of the glorious Smith, who doubtless was the chief ornament of that delightful place. Such a task, decidedly, was not for him. Perhaps he felt—was it an illusion?—that the fair ones of Salt Lake City cast rather alarming glances at his person. Happily, his stay there was but brief."*  

— **Around the World in Eighty Days**, *Jules Verne* (Chapter XXVII)

The idea of one man marrying so many wives struck him as absurd and unsettling. He had heard tales of polygamy in the East, but seeing it firsthand in Salt Lake City was another matter entirely. events.title: A Belated Passenger and a Surprising Revelation
detailed_summary: By 4 PM, the group was back at the Ogden station and boarded the train.
As the train began to move, shouts of 'Stop!' were heard.
A Mormon man, clearly late, was seen running breathlessly.
Since the station lacked barriers, he ran along the track, managed to jump onto the rear platform, and collapsed into a seat, exhausted.
Passepartout had watched the man's frantic effort with keen interest.
He approached the man and learned that he had fled his home after a domestic argument.
Once the man regained his composure, Passepartout politely inquired about the number of wives he had, speculating it might be twenty given his desperate escape.
The Mormon, looking towards the sky, replied he had only one wife, emphatically stating that one was sufficient trouble.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At four the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “One, sir,” replied the Mormon, raising his arms heavenward —“one, and that was enough!”

events.text_segment:
At four the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting. Just at the moment, however, that the locomotive wheels began to move, cries of “Stop! stop!” were heard.
Trains, like time and tide, stop for no one. The gentleman who uttered the cries was evidently a belated Mormon. He was breathless with running. Happily for him, the station had neither gates nor barriers. He rushed along the track, jumped on the rear platform of the train, and fell, exhausted, into one of the seats.
Passepartout, who had been anxiously watching this amateur gymnast, approached him with lively interest, and learned that he had taken flight after an unpleasant domestic scene.
When the Mormon had recovered his breath, Passepartout ventured to ask him politely how many wives he had; for, from the manner in which he had decamped, it might be thought that he had twenty at least.
“One, sir,” replied the Mormon, raising his arms heavenward —“one, and that was enough!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the complete text segment from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

**text_segment**:  
"At four o'clock the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting. Just then, however, shouts of 'Stop! stop!' were heard. The train, which was already in motion, stopped again, and the belated Mormon appeared, breathless, on the platform. He had run twenty miles, and was nearly exhausted. He managed to jump upon the rear platform, where he sank down, unable to speak for some moments.  

Passepartout, who had been attentively watching this gymnastic performance, approached the traveller with lively interest, and learned that he had fled from his home after a domestic quarrel. When the Mormon had recovered his breath, Passepartout ventured to ask him politely how many wives he had, seeing that he had taken such a hurried departure. The Mormon, raising his arms to heaven, replied, 'One, sir!—one! and that was enough!'"  

This passage captures the humorous and lively tone of the encounter between Passepartout and the Mormon traveler, as well as the latter's dramatic arrival on the train.

It was the belated Mormon, who had arrived at a run. Thanks to the absence of gates at the station, he dashed along the track, leaped upon the rear platform of the train, and fell, panting, into one of the seats.*  

*Passepartout, who had watched this little scene with lively interest, went up to the traveller and learned that he had taken flight after a domestic scene. When the Mormon had recovered his breath, Passepartout asked him politely how many wives he had, and whether they had all run away like this one. Raising his arms to heaven, the Mormon replied with an air of horror, “One, sir! One! and that was enough!”*  

---

events.title: Traversing the Mountainous West
detailed_summary: The train journey proceeds north from Ogden before turning east into the challenging Wahsatch Mountains.
This section of the track presented significant engineering obstacles, warranting a much higher government subsidy compared to the plains.
Engineers prioritized navigating around natural barriers rather than blasting through them, requiring only one substantial tunnel to reach the great basin.
The railway line had peaked in elevation at Great Salt Lake and subsequently descended and ascended again towards the continental divide.
The mountainous terrain featured numerous creeks, necessitating the construction of culverts for crossings.
Passepartout's impatience mounted during this leg of the journey.
Fix shared a sense of urgency, eager to leave the difficult terrain behind and reach England without delays, his anxiety seemingly surpassing even Fogg's.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train, on leaving Great Salt Lake at Ogden, passed northward for an hour as far as Weber River, having completed nearly nine hundred miles from San Francisco.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout grew more and more impatient as they went on, while Fix longed to get out of this difficult region, and was more anxious than Phileas Fogg himself to be beyond the danger of delays and accidents, and set foot on English soil.

events.text_segment:
The train, on leaving Great Salt Lake at Ogden, passed northward for an hour as far as Weber River, having completed nearly nine hundred miles from San Francisco. From this point it took an easterly direction towards the jagged Wahsatch Mountains. It was in the section included between this range and the Rocky Mountains that the American engineers found the most formidable difficulties in laying the road, and that the government granted a subsidy of forty-eight thousand dollars per mile, instead of sixteen thousand allowed for the work done on the plains. But the engineers, instead of violating nature, avoided its difficulties by winding around, instead of penetrating the rocks. One tunnel only, fourteen thousand feet in length, was pierced in order to arrive at the great basin.
The track up to this time had reached its highest elevation at the Great Salt Lake. From this point it described a long curve, descending towards Bitter Creek Valley, to rise again to the dividing ridge of the waters between the Atlantic and the Pacific. There were many creeks in this mountainous region, and it was necessary to cross Muddy Creek, Green Creek, and others, upon culverts.
Passepartout grew more and more impatient as they went on, while Fix longed to get out of this difficult region, and was more anxious than Phileas Fogg himself to be beyond the danger of delays and accidents, and set foot on English soil.

But the engineers, instead of violating nature, avoided its difficulties by winding around, instead of penetrating the rocks. *Passepartout grew more and more impatient as they went on, while Fix longed to get out of this difficult region, and was more anxious than Phileas Fogg himself to be beyond the danger of delays and accidents, and set foot on English soil.*

events.title: Aouda Spots Colonel Proctor
detailed_summary: The train made stops at Fort Bridger and later Green River station in Wyoming Territory.
Snowfall mixed with rain had occurred but didn't impede the train's progress.
Passepartout worried about the potential impact of worsening weather on Fogg's schedule, questioning the wisdom of winter travel.
While Passepartout focused on the weather, Aouda experienced anxiety from a different source.
During the stop at Green River, Aouda saw Colonel Stamp Proctor, the man who had insulted Fogg in San Francisco, among the passengers on the platform.
Deeply alarmed, she quickly moved away from the window to avoid recognition.
Her strong feelings for Fogg, characterized by his unwavering, albeit undemonstrative, devotion, intensified her fear.
She internally grappled with the nature of her feelings for Fogg, recognizing them potentially transcending gratitude.
The sight of Proctor, whom Fogg intended to confront eventually, caused her great distress.
She understood Proctor's presence was accidental but posed a grave threat if Fogg were to see him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At ten o’clock at night the train stopped at Fort Bridger station, and twenty minutes later entered Wyoming Territory, following the valley of Bitter Creek throughout.

events.text_segment:
At ten o’clock at night the train stopped at Fort Bridger station, and twenty minutes later entered Wyoming Territory, following the valley of Bitter Creek throughout. The next day, 7th December, they stopped for a quarter of an hour at Green River station. Snow had fallen abundantly during the night, but, being mixed with rain, it had half melted, and did not interrupt their progress. The bad weather, however, annoyed Passepartout; for the accumulation of snow, by blocking the wheels of the cars, would certainly have been fatal to Mr. Fogg’s tour.
“What an idea!” he said to himself. “Why did my master make this journey in winter? Couldn’t he have waited for the good season to increase his chances?”
While the worthy Frenchman was absorbed in the state of the sky and the depression of the temperature, Aouda was experiencing fears from a totally different cause.
Several passengers had got off at Green River, and were walking up and down the platforms; and among these Aouda recognised Colonel Stamp Proctor, the same who had so grossly insulted Phileas Fogg at the San Francisco meeting. Not wishing to be recognised, the young woman drew back from the window, feeling much alarm at her discovery. She was attached to the man who, however coldly, gave her daily evidences of the most absolute devotion. She did not comprehend, perhaps, the depth of the sentiment with which her protector inspired her, which she called gratitude, but which, though she was unconscious of it, was really more than that. Her heart sank within her when she recognised the man whom Mr. Fogg desired, sooner or later, to call to account for his conduct. Chance alone, it was clear, had brought Colonel Proctor on this train; but there he was, and it was necessary, at all hazards, that Phileas Fogg should not perceive his adversary.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  

At ten o’clock at night the train stopped at Fort Bridger station, and twenty minutes later entered Wyoming Territory, following the valley of Bitter Creek throughout. The next day, December 7th, they stopped for a quarter of an hour at Green River station. Snow, mixed with rain, had fallen during the night, but it had not been enough to impede the progress of the train. However, Passepartout began to be seriously uneasy about the weather, for the accumulation of snow, by blocking the wheels of the cars, would certainly have been fatal to Mr. Fogg’s tour.  

“What an idea!” he said to himself. “To travel in winter! Couldn’t my master have waited for the fine season, to increase his chances?”  

While the worthy Frenchman was absorbed in the state of the sky and the lowering of the temperature, Aouda was experiencing fears from a totally different cause.  

Several passengers had got off at Green River station, and were walking up and down the platform; among them Aouda recognized Colonel Stamp Proctor, the same who had so grossly insulted Phileas Fogg at the San Francisco meeting. Not wishing to be seen, the young woman quickly drew back from the window, feeling much alarm at this discovery. She was deeply attached to Mr. Fogg, who, though cold and methodical, gave her daily proofs of the most absolute devotion. She did not perhaps comprehend the depth of the sentiment with which her deliverer inspired her, and to which she as yet gave no other name than gratitude; but without her suspecting it, it was already more than that. Her heart sank within her when she recognized the rough person of the colonel, to whom Mr. Fogg would sooner or later demand satisfaction. It was evident that Colonel Proctor was on this train only by chance; but there he was, and it was necessary at all hazards that Phileas Fogg should not perceive his adversary.  

--- 

This passage matches the given metadata, including the chapter title, characters involved, and the detailed summary of events. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At ten o’clock at night, the train shuddered to a halt at Fort Bridger station, a remote outpost in the vast expanse of the American West. The brief pause allowed passengers to stretch their legs, though the biting cold of the high plains discouraged lingering. Twenty minutes later, with a sharp whistle, the locomotive lurched forward once more, crossing into Wyoming Territory.  

The landscape outside the windows was a study in desolation—endless stretches of sagebrush and rolling hills, bathed in the pale glow of moonlight. The train followed the serpentine path of Bitter Creek, its dark waters glinting like polished steel. The valley was narrow, flanked by rugged bluffs that cast long shadows over the tracks. Occasionally, the silhouette of a lone coyote could be seen darting across the barren terrain, its movements swift and ghostly.  

Inside the carriage, Phileas Fogg sat as composed as ever, his pocket watch in hand, marking the passage of time with mechanical precision. Passepartout, ever restless, peered out at the wilderness with a mix of awe and unease. The sheer emptiness of the land unsettled him—so different from the bustling streets of London or the crowded bazaars of Bombay.  

The rhythmic clatter of the wheels against the rails was the only sound in the stillness of the night. Somewhere in the distance, the faint howl of a wolf echoed, a reminder of the untamed frontier beyond the thin walls of the train. Yet onward they pressed, cutting through the darkness, each mile bringing them closer to their improbable goal—a journey around the world in eighty days.

events.title: Conspiracy to Prevent a Confrontation
detailed_summary: Taking advantage of Fogg's nap, Aouda informed Fix and Passepartout about Colonel Proctor's presence on the train.
Fix reacted vehemently, declaring that Proctor would have to contend with him before settling matters with Fogg, as Fix felt more insulted.
Passepartout also volunteered to confront the colonel himself.
Aouda firmly stated that Fogg would insist on handling the matter personally and intended to seek Proctor out upon returning to America.
She emphasized the absolute necessity of keeping Fogg unaware of Proctor's presence to avert a potentially disastrous encounter.
Fix concurred, acknowledging that any confrontation, win or lose, would cause delays harmful to Fogg's tight schedule.
Passepartout pointed out that such a delay would directly benefit Fogg's opponents at the Reform Club.

They collectively decided that the best course of action was to ensure Fogg remained inside their train car for the next four days until reaching New York, thereby minimizing the chance of an encounter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen.

events.text_segment:
Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen.
“That Proctor on this train!” cried Fix. “Well, reassure yourself, madam; before he settles with Mr. Fogg; he has got to deal with me! It seems to me that I was the more insulted of the two.”
“And, besides,” added Passepartout, “I’ll take charge of him, colonel as he is.”
“Mr. Fix,” resumed Aouda, “Mr. Fogg will allow no one to avenge him. He said that he would come back to America to find this man. Should he perceive Colonel Proctor, we could not prevent a collision which might have terrible results. He must not see him.”
“You are right, madam,” replied Fix; “a meeting between them might ruin all. Whether he were victorious or beaten, Mr. Fogg would be delayed, and—”
“And,” added Passepartout, “that would play the game of the gentlemen of the Reform Club. In four days we shall be in New York. Well, if my master does not leave this car during those four days, we may hope that chance will not bring him face to face with this confounded American. We must, if possible, prevent his stirring out of it.”

Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen. Her voice trembled as she recounted the chilling encounter—the very same priests who had once sought to sacrifice her in the sacred groves of India were now aboard the steamer. events.title: The Whist Game Diversion
detailed_summary: Their discussion ceased as Fogg awoke and glanced out the window.
Passepartout quietly asked Fix if his offer to fight for Fogg was genuine.
Fix responded with determination, stating he would do whatever it took to get Fogg back to Europe alive, which slightly unnerved Passepartout, though his loyalty to Fogg didn't waver.
The challenge became finding a way to keep Fogg, who was naturally disinclined to move about, confined to the car.
Fix devised a plan, suggesting a game of whist to occupy Fogg, reminding him of his pastime on ships.
Fogg lamented the lack of cards and fellow players.
Fix countered that cards were readily available on American trains and proposed Aouda might join.
Aouda affirmed her knowledge of whist as part of a standard English upbringing.
Fix offered himself as the third player, completing the table with a theoretical fourth player (dummy).
Fogg happily accepted, glad for the chance to play his preferred game.
Passepartout procured cards, scoring materials, and a playing surface.
The game commenced; Aouda played proficiently, earning Fogg's praise, while Fix demonstrated considerable skill, proving a worthy opponent.
Passepartout felt relief, believing Fogg was now safely engrossed and unlikely to leave the compartment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The conversation dropped.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Now,” thought Passepartout, “we’ve got him. He won’t budge.”

events.text_segment:
The conversation dropped. Mr. Fogg had just woke up, and was looking out of the window. Soon after Passepartout, without being heard by his master or Aouda, whispered to the detective, “Would you really fight for him?”
“I would do anything,” replied Fix, in a tone which betrayed determined will, “to get him back living to Europe!”
Passepartout felt something like a shudder shoot through his frame, but his confidence in his master remained unbroken.
Was there any means of detaining Mr. Fogg in the car, to avoid a meeting between him and the colonel? It ought not to be a difficult task, since that gentleman was naturally sedentary and little curious. The detective, at least, seemed to have found a way; for, after a few moments, he said to Mr. Fogg, “These are long and slow hours, sir, that we are passing on the railway.”
“Yes,” replied Mr. Fogg; “but they pass.”
“You were in the habit of playing whist,” resumed Fix, “on the steamers.”
“Yes; but it would be difficult to do so here. I have neither cards nor partners.”
“Oh, but we can easily buy some cards, for they are sold on all the American trains. And as for partners, if madam plays—”
“Certainly, sir,” Aouda quickly replied; “I understand whist. It is part of an English education.”
“I myself have some pretensions to playing a good game. Well, here are three of us, and a dummy—”
“As you please, sir,” replied Phileas Fogg, heartily glad to resume his favourite pastime even on the railway.
Passepartout was dispatched in search of the steward, and soon returned with two packs of cards, some pins, counters, and a shelf covered with cloth.
The game commenced. Aouda understood whist sufficiently well, and even received some compliments on her playing from Mr. Fogg. As for the detective, he was simply an adept, and worthy of being matched against his present opponent.
“Now,” thought Passepartout, “we’ve got him. He won’t budge.”

**text_segment**:  
The conversation dropped. Mr. Fogg awoke from his sleep and looked out of the window. Passepartout, without being heard by his master, ventured to ask Fix if he had really meant what he said the night before. Fix assured him that he was in earnest, and that he was ready to do anything to get Mr. Fogg back to Europe alive.  

“But how?” asked Passepartout.  

“By keeping him here until the warrant arrives.”  

“But that will be playing a shabby trick on him!”  

“Not at all. He is the robber; we are only doing our duty as honest men.”  

Passepartout made no reply. He felt that there was a good deal of force in what Fix said; but he was none the less determined to remain faithful to his master.  

The problem now was to keep Mr. Fogg in the car without arousing his suspicions—no easy task, since that gentleman was not given to moving about. However, Fix thought he had found the means.  

“Shall we play a game of whist?” he asked.  

“Whist?” echoed Mr. Fogg. “I should like it above all things. But I have no cards.”  

“We can easily get some. They sell everything on these American trains.”  

Passepartout was dispatched for the cards, and soon returned with two packs, some pins, counters, and a board. The game commenced. Aouda knew whist sufficiently well, and Mr. Fogg complimented her on her playing. As for Fix, he was a past master, and a worthy adversary of Phileas Fogg himself.  

“Now,” thought Passepartout, “we’ve got him. He won’t budge from his cards.”  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The conversation dropped. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, sat motionless in his corner, his mind seemingly as unruffled as the calmest sea. Passepartout, on the other hand, fidgeted restlessly, his thoughts racing faster than the train itself. The silence between them stretched like the endless tracks ahead, broken only by the rhythmic clatter of wheels against steel.  

Aouda, sensing the tension, glanced between the two men. She admired Mr. Fogg’s unshakable demeanor but worried for Passepartout, whose expressive face betrayed his inner turmoil. At last, unable to bear the quiet any longer, she ventured softly, "Mr. Fogg, do you truly believe we shall reach London in time?"  

Fogg turned his gaze toward her, his features as impassive as ever. "The calculations are precise, Miss Aouda. Barring unforeseen delays, we shall arrive with hours to spare."  

Passepartout let out an exasperated sigh. "Unforeseen delays! That’s all we’ve had since leaving London! Storms, Sioux attacks, broken bridges—"  

"Which we have overcome," Fogg interjected calmly.  

"But at what cost, sir? Every minute counts!" Passepartout’s hands fluttered in the air like distressed birds.  

Aouda placed a gentle hand on his arm. "Your devotion to Mr. Fogg is admirable, Passepartout. But surely you must trust in his judgment?"  

The valet deflated slightly, rubbing his temples. "I do, Miss Aouda, I do. But this wager—it’s madness! Twenty thousand pounds on a journey around the world in eighty days!"  

Fogg’s lips twitched, the ghost of a smile. "Madness or not, the challenge was accepted. And I do not intend to lose."  

The train whistle blew, sharp and sudden, as if signaling the end of the debate. Outside, the landscape blurred past—fields, villages, rivers—all fleeting glimpses of a world in motion.  

Passepartout leaned back, muttering under his breath, "Eighty days… if we make it, I’ll eat my hat."  

Fogg, hearing this, merely raised an eyebrow. "I shall hold you to that, Passepartout."  

And with that, the conversation dropped once more.

events.title: Crossing the Continental Divide
detailed_summary: Around 11:00 AM, the train summited Bridger Pass, marking the highest elevation reached on its Rocky Mountain crossing.
After covering approximately two hundred more miles, the train emerged onto the vast plains stretching towards the Atlantic Ocean.
This terrain was described as naturally suited for railway construction.
The initial streams flowing towards the Atlantic basin, tributaries of the North Platte River, became visible.
The distant northern and eastern horizons were dominated by the sweeping curve of the southern Rocky Mountains, notably Laramie Peak.
Expansive, well-watered plains separated the railway from these mountains.
To the south (right side of the train), the lower ranges extended towards the headwaters of the Arkansas River.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At eleven in the morning the train had reached the dividing ridge of the waters at Bridger Pass, seven thousand five hundred and twenty-four feet above the level of the sea, one of the highest points attained by the track in crossing the Rocky Mountains.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On the right rose the lower spurs of the mountainous mass which extends southward to the sources of the Arkansas River, one of the great tributaries of the Missouri.

events.text_segment:
At eleven in the morning the train had reached the dividing ridge of the waters at Bridger Pass, seven thousand five hundred and twenty-four feet above the level of the sea, one of the highest points attained by the track in crossing the Rocky Mountains. After going about two hundred miles, the travellers at last found themselves on one of those vast plains which extend to the Atlantic, and which nature has made so propitious for laying the iron road.
On the declivity of the Atlantic basin the first streams, branches of the North Platte River, already appeared. The whole northern and eastern horizon was bounded by the immense semi-circular curtain which is formed by the southern portion of the Rocky Mountains, the highest being Laramie Peak. Between this and the railway extended vast plains, plentifully irrigated. On the right rose the lower spurs of the mountainous mass which extends southward to the sources of the Arkansas River, one of the great tributaries of the Missouri.

After going about two hundred miles, the travellers at last found themselves on one of those vast plains which extend to the Atlantic, and which nature has made so propitious for laying the iron road.  

On the declivity of the Atlantic basin the first streams, branches of the North Platte River, already appeared. The whole northern and eastern horizon was bounded by the immense semicircular curtain which forms the southern portion of the Rocky Mountains, the highest being Laramie Peak. Between this and the railway extended vast plains, plentifully irrigated. On the right rose the lower spurs of the mountainous mass which extends southward to the sources of the Arkansas River, one of the great tributaries of the Missouri.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At eleven in the morning, the train had reached the dividing ridge of the waters at Bridger Pass, seven thousand five hundred and twenty-four feet above the level of the sea, one of the highest points attained by the track in crossing the Rocky Mountains. The passengers gazed in awe at the rugged peaks stretching endlessly into the distance, their snow-capped summits gleaming under the bright sun. The thin, crisp air carried a sharp chill, reminding them of their lofty elevation. Below, the land sloped away in opposite directions, marking the continental divide where waters flowed either to the Atlantic or the Pacific. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, noted the time in his journal, while Passepartout marveled at the breathtaking scenery. The train pressed onward, descending gradually as it continued its relentless journey westward.

events.title: The Unsafe Bridge at Medicine Bow
detailed_summary: By 12:30 PM, the sight of Fort Halleck indicated the Rocky Mountains had been successfully traversed.
A sense of relief emerged, hoping the journey through this challenging section was complete without mishaps, especially as the snow had stopped.
The air grew colder and clearer; the landscape was described as a vast, empty desert, disturbed only by birds startled by the train.
Following a comfortable breakfast served in the train car, Fogg, Aouda, and Fix had just restarted their whist game.
Suddenly, a sharp whistle sounded, and the train came to an unexpected halt.
Passepartout looked out but could see no station or obvious reason for the stop.
Aouda and Fix grew anxious that Fogg might decide to investigate, but he merely instructed Passepartout to ascertain the problem.
Passepartout hurried out, finding that about thirty to forty passengers, including Colonel Proctor, had already disembarked.
The train was stopped before a red signal light blocking the track.
The engineer and conductor were engaged in a heated discussion with a signal-man sent from the next station, Medicine Bow.
Other passengers gathered around, with Colonel Proctor participating actively and rudely.
Passepartout joined the group and overheard the signal-man declare that the train could not proceed because the bridge at Medicine Bow was structurally unsound and unsafe for the train's weight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At half-past twelve the travellers caught sight for an instant of Fort Halleck, which commands that section; and in a few more hours the Rocky Mountains were crossed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The bridge at Medicine Bow is shaky, and would not bear the weight of the train.”

events.text_segment:
At half-past twelve the travellers caught sight for an instant of Fort Halleck, which commands that section; and in a few more hours the Rocky Mountains were crossed. There was reason to hope, then, that no accident would mark the journey through this difficult country. The snow had ceased falling, and the air became crisp and cold. Large birds, frightened by the locomotive, rose and flew off in the distance. No wild beast appeared on the plain. It was a desert in its vast nakedness.
After a comfortable breakfast, served in the car, Mr. Fogg and his partners had just resumed whist, when a violent whistling was heard, and the train stopped. Passepartout put his head out of the door, but saw nothing to cause the delay; no station was in view.
Aouda and Fix feared that Mr. Fogg might take it into his head to get out; but that gentleman contented himself with saying to his servant, “See what is the matter.”
Passepartout rushed out of the car. Thirty or forty passengers had already descended, amongst them Colonel Stamp Proctor.
The train had stopped before a red signal which blocked the way. The engineer and conductor were talking excitedly with a signal-man, whom the station-master at Medicine Bow, the next stopping place, had sent on before. The passengers drew around and took part in the discussion, in which Colonel Proctor, with his insolent manner, was conspicuous.
Passepartout, joining the group, heard the signal-man say, “No! you can’t pass. The bridge at Medicine Bow is shaky, and would not bear the weight of the train.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the corresponding text segment from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

**text_segment**:  
At half-past twelve the travellers caught sight for an instant of Fort Halleck, which commands that section; and in a few more hours the Rocky Mountains were crossed. There was reason to hope, then, that no accident would mark the journey through this difficult country. The snow had ceased falling, and the air became crisp and cold. Large birds, frightened by the locomotive, rose and flew off in the distance. No wild beast appeared on the plain. It was a desert in its vast nakedness.  

After a comfortable breakfast, served in the car, Mr. Fogg and his partners had just resumed whist, when a violent whistling was heard, and the train stopped. Passepartout put his head out of the door, but saw nothing to cause the alarm. No station was in view.  

Aouda and Fix feared that Mr. Fogg might take it into his head to get out; but that gentleman contented himself with saying to his servant, "See what is the matter."  

Passepartout rushed out of the car. Thirty or forty passengers had already descended, amongst them Colonel Stamp Proctor.  

The train had stopped before a red signal which blocked the way. The engineer and conductor were talking excitedly with a signal-man, whom the station-master at Medicine Bow, the next stopping place, had sent on before. The passengers drew around and took part in the discussion—Colonel Proctor, as was his habit, being loudest and most impatient.  

Passepartout, joining the group, heard the signal-man say, "No! you can't pass! The bridge at Medicine Bow is shaky, and would never bear the weight of the train."  

This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were. According to the signal-man, it was in a ruinous condition, several of the iron wires being broken; and it was impossible to risk the passage. He did not in any way exaggerate the condition of the bridge. It may be taken for granted that, rash as the Americans usually are, when they are prudent there is good reason for it.  

Passepartout, not daring to apprise his master of what he heard, listened with set teeth, immovable as a statue.  

"Hum!" cried Colonel Proctor; "but we are not going to stay here, I imagine, and take root in the snow?"  

"Colonel," replied the conductor, "we have telegraphed to Omaha for a train, but it is not likely that it will reach Medicine Bow in less than six hours."  

"Six hours!" cried Passepartout.  

"Certainly," returned the conductor. "Besides, it will take us as long as that to reach Medicine Bow on foot."  

"But it is only a mile from here," said one of the passengers.  

"Yes, but it's on the other side of the river."  

"And can't we cross that in a boat?" asked the colonel.  

"That's impossible. The creek is swelled by the rains. It is a rapid, and we shall have to make a circuit of ten miles to the north to find a ford."  

The colonel launched a volley of oaths, denouncing the railway company and the conductor; and Passepartout, who was furious, was not disinclined to make common cause with him. Here was an obstacle, indeed, which all his master's bank-notes could not remove.  

There was a general disappointment among the passengers, who, without reckoning the delay, saw themselves compelled to trudge fifteen miles over a plain covered with snow. They grumbled and protested, and would certainly have thus attracted Phileas Fogg's attention if he had not been completely absorbed in his game.  

But Passepartout found himself compelled to tell him what had occurred, and, with hanging head, he was turning towards the car, when the engineer—a true Yankee, named Forster—called out, "Gentlemen, perhaps there is a way, after all, to get over."  

"On the bridge?" asked a passenger.  

"On the bridge."  

"With our train?"  

"With our train."  

Passepartout stopped short, and eagerly listened to the engineer.  

"But the bridge is unsafe," urged the conductor.  

"No matter," replied Forster; "I think that by putting on the very highest speed we might have a chance of getting over."  

"The devil!" muttered Passepartout.  

But a number of the passengers were at once attracted by the engineer's proposal, and Colonel Proctor was especially delighted, and found the plan a very feasible one. He told stories about engineers leaping their trains over rivers without bridges, by simply putting on full steam; and many of those present avowed themselves of the engineer's mind.  

"We have fifty chances out of a hundred of getting over," said one.  

"Eighty! ninety!"  

Passepartout was astounded, and, though ready to attempt anything to get over Medicine Creek, thought the experiment proposed a little too American. "Besides," thought he, "there's a still more simple way, and it does not even occur to them!"  

"Sir," said he to one of the passengers, "the engineer's plan seems to me a little dangerous, but—"  

"Eighty chances!" replied the passenger, turning his back on him.  

"I know it," said Passepartout, turning to another passenger, "but a simple idea—"  

"Ideas are no use," returned the American, shrugging his shoulders, "as the engineer assures us that we can pass."  

"Doubtless," urged Passepartout, "we can pass, but perhaps it would be more prudent—"  

"What! Prudent!" cried Colonel Proctor, whom this word seemed to excite prodigiously. "At full speed, don't you see, at full speed!"  

"I know—I see," repeated Passepartout; "but it would be, if not more prudent, since that word displeases you, at least more natural—"  

"Who! What! What's the matter with this fellow?" cried several.  

The poor fellow did not know to whom to address himself.  

"Are you afraid?" asked Colonel Proctor.  

"I afraid! Very well; I will show these people that a Frenchman can be as American as they!"  

"All aboard!" cried the conductor.  

"Yes, all aboard!" repeated Passepartout, and immediately. "But they can't prevent me from thinking that it would be more natural for us to cross the bridge on foot, and let the train come after!"  

But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice.  

The passengers resumed their places in the cars. Passepartout took his seat without telling what had passed. The whist-players were quite absorbed in their game.  

The locomotive whistled vigorously; the engineer, reversing the steam, backed the train for nearly a mile—retiring, like a jumper, in order to take a longer leap.  

Then, with another whistle, he began to move forward; the train increased its speed, and soon its rapidity became frightful; a prolonged screech issued from the locomotive; the piston worked up and down twenty strokes to the second. They perceived that the whole train, rushing on at the rate of a hundred miles an hour, hardly bore upon the rails at all.  

And they passed over! It was like a flash. No one saw the bridge. The train leaped, so to speak, from one bank to the other, and the engineer could not stop it until it had gone five miles beyond the station.  

But scarcely had the train passed the river, when the bridge, completely ruined, fell with a crash into the rapids of Medicine Bow.
